description:
I came here before going to a concert at The Fillmore and was expecting them to have no vegan options so I was in a bad mood.  But we asked the waitress if they have vegan options and they surprisingly have a decent amount (which definitely cheered me up)!  Here's what she told us:

Vegetable Udon - vegan, I confirmed there is no fish in the broth
Bibimbap and Dol Sot Bibimbap - order it with tofu instead of beef and no egg
Soft Tofu Soup - order it without the beef and clam in the soup, and no egg

I had the vegetable udon and it was just ok.  Next time I'll try the soft tofu soup.
author: Sydney W.

description:
Came here with my girlfriends as they've eaten here before. My first time of course. Food ordered was... spicy rice cake with ramen noodles, fried chicken and kimchi bibimbap. The only disappointing dish was the fried chicken. A bit bland, but the other 2 dishes were nice and tasty. Cute little joint, nice atmosphere and workers all seemed nice. The location isn't the most attractive but ample parking space.

Definitely if ever back in this neighborhood, we'll try other items from the menu.
author: Nance L.

description:
Needed a quick bite after watching a concert. Place was opened late so we decided to give it a try. Food was decent but not the best. They do give bon chon but it didn't taste as "authentic" or fresh as other places. The potato salad tasted like it was from Safeway. 
For our food we ordered the Kimchee pancakes, kimchee fried rice, and the soft tofu soup. The pancakes looked amazing! They tasted good but a little too heavy on the onions in my opinion. The kimchee fries rice wasn't that great. Kinda bland and felt like the ingredients weren't cooked or blended well together. My favorite was the soup. It was a cold-walk from the concert venue to the restaurant, so the soup really hit the spot! Great flavor and tofu was nice and soft.
Good for a late night snack, especially if you are around the Filmore. Not too many options at night other than Subway.
author: Christian N.

description:
We were in J/Town and needed a quick bite. 
This was at the very end of the plaza where they had an adorable layout inside. The booths also had accessible plugs right above the condiments so it looks like a really convenient place to chill while charging your phone during your meal.

The food was affordable and alright. Their sides weren't too good besides their seaweed. I love how they have barley tea as a given and of course tbeee small sides with our meal. Compared to other Korean places, I'm not sure how it is like in the SF scene. I come from the LA and visit Ktown often, so this place below average compared. But given with the overall food place I've visited in SF, I'd say this place is okay. I see regulars coming in for tofu soup, so their speciality seems like its for that.
author: Linda X.

description:
I absolutely love this place. Good service, Good price and Amazing food . But if you're like me and love a quality late night meal, this place is perfect .. I  always ordered Jok bal ,soon tofu soup and beef I really love it, everythings taste so so good!  
I'll definitely come back again! I recommend this restaurant for you....
author: Khuhathai K.

description:
AI Tang !!! Roe of pollack soup.( medium spicy )
It was better in winter day.
author: Suparadar M.

description:
Visited Thurs, Feb 22 2017 @ 11PM

We ordered...
Main Meals: Kimchi fried rice, BBQ beef, yuk gae jang

Service: A bit slow to get our food and since it was late, there was only one server who seemed a bit stretched, but he was perfectly friendly and as attentive as he could be
Vibe: Cozy lighting, comfy booths, karaoke next door
Good for: Late night eats and hangouts

Overall verdict: Love their Banchan! Would definitely come back for late night eats
author: Diana C.

description:
Came in for a quick dinner with friends on Saturday night around 6 pm. Pretty empty, only two or three tables were occupied. 

Prices are pretty standard, 13-15$ a dish. 

Side dishes are diverse and pretty yummy, and came out almost immediately when we sat down. Also appreciated the complimentary hot barley tea-- it was cold AF outside. 

I got the kimchi fried rice. It comes with a fried egg on top and some cabbage on the side. Food comes out pretty quickly and everything is steamy and hot. 

Service is fast and minimal. Good spot for a quick casual dinner for those Korean food cravings.
author: RachEl L.

description: What happened to the Korean owners?  Now it's all non Korean workers here.  They are not really quick or efficient and stingy with the donkatsu sauce and side dishes (you have to order an "entree" to get the side dishes even if you order 3 things).  We ordered neng myun, tonkatsu and omelet and that was not enough for the side dishes.  Really?  Stingy all around, bad service and need to find a new real Korean place.  They don't even speak Korean here.  Fake Korean place with bad service.
author: Chris L.

description: Korean restaurant located in Fillmore right next to Japantown.  I thought my soup was pretty good and my parents ordered set boxes which consisted of a lot of food.  I would recommend getting that option if you're hungry (it's also a good deal).
author: Mikayla M.

description: Been coming here for years, but they changed ownership like two or three years back. Food is still good but flavor is a little different. Love this hole in the wall next to japantown. I get their casseroles to share (large is way better value than the single serving) and their pork feet! DEAR GOD THEIR PORK FEET IS THE BEST IVE EVER HAD. Their lunch bentos are also really tasty
author: Iris W.

description:
Good spot for who want to try Korean food which is great and reasonably priced for the portion. 
Service was very friendly. We ordered  big pot one called Assorted meat varieties for two people and B.B.Q short rib plate that marinated with their house special sauce was so juicy good combination with soju. Can't wait to visit again..
author: Pop J.

description:
I enjoyed their seafood bibimbap! The price was pretty standard ($13.95), and there was a good portion of seafood and veggies in the mix. While the gochujang sauce was a bit generous, the dish was still tasty.

This isn't five stars because their banchan is a bit limited in comparison to other places I've gone to in the city. At least they had some essentials though (kimchi and seaweed)!
author: Camille E.

description:
I went to Arang Yesterday night. 
I ordered short rib plate and Budae Soup for 2 people. Foods are still good taste and great quality. 
Definitely in LOVe with Korean food at this place. 
Excellent foods and Excellent services. 
Will come back again for sure!!
author: Patnaree S.

description: Late night meal. Food is great! I don't mind coming back. In that time, food came in pretty quick. Thanks Arang.
author: Joe T.

description: This is my favorite korean restaurant. They have variety of food, rice , soup and so many kind of side dishes. I had some soup today. Ordered budae jie gae, it came with rice and 6 kind of side dishes. I really enjoyed eating. They also have some alcohol, it's a great spot to hang out.
author: Jo I.

description: The food is good. Love the Korean rice cake. The soup is good. And it's comes with rice. The waiter is nice. Definitely will come back again
author: Clancy Y.

description: I love this place!!! It's one of my favorite Korean restaurants in San Francisco. All the ladies working here are so nice. They have nice selection of all different kinds of Korean dishes with a very decent price. So recommend!!!
author: Mina L.

description:
One of my favorite go to places for Korean food.  They're always playing K-pop here which makes the environment fun.  It's located in the same plaza as Safeway so there is plenty of parking.  Just remember to lock your car and not leave any valuables visible.

I normally come here for the Kim chi fried rice whenever I'm in the city and wanting Korean food.  If you run out of sides, they'll bring you more.  Their galbi, soft tofu soup, and roasted rice tea is so good.  Service can get a bit slow when the place is full.  I believe they only have two people working as waitresses.
author: Jenni T.

description: My wife and I stumbled in here after everything closed at night. We were so pleased with everything! They were so sweet and attentive to us! It was great service! The food was also incredible! It was very well prepared and presented. The portion sizes were also really big. I would most certainly recommend coming here and we will be back!
author: Cameron D.

description:
Sooooooooo delicious!  I come here for the lunch specials whenever I can, only available on weekdays.  Spicy pork is amazing!  My son enjoys the lunch combo so much, he even eats the salad ~ FTW!  

Service is attentive and the K-pop music playing in the background makes it feel like Gangnam Style up in here (minus Psy)!  I used to kick it around this side of Fillmore in my teens, singing late night Karaoke upstairs next door.  My friends and I were so COOL back then, try telling that to our kids now...they don't believe us HA!  

Get the spicy pork if you like it SPICY ~ WHOOP, WHOOP! 

http://giphy.com/gifs/reaction-dancing-korea-zAxEQ8b0IkLTi
author: Christine R.

description: Great place for groups. Soup was delicious. This is our favorite Korean restaurant. Completely authentic. Like eating in Korea, Food quality very high. Prices very reasonable. Free parking!!! Servers are friendly.
author: Eric E.

description: Customer service is fast, friendly and prompt. The food quality is consistent and great tasting. I love how there are outlets at the table so it's convenient when my phone is dying or when I want to study. No wifi and the music is a bit loud. Homey ambiance.
author: Daw M.

description:
This is my favorite Korean restaurant in SF. I come here to eat Kalbi, Dolsot bibimbab, and army soup almost every week. They serve banchan which are so good like real homemade. And their prices are very reasonable.
I highly recommend this restaurant if someone wants to try Korean food.
author: Chrish K.

description: Food is alright here. Stop by whenever I'm in the area. Bad day to come in. Waiting for over 30min for my takeout of kimchi fried rice. No other customers right now too. Seems like they doing a photo shoot of their entrees....
author: La G.

description:
Brr! San Francisco gets cold! And this place will take that chill right out of your bones! 

My favorite Korean soup is the seafood tofu soup, and this place ranks up there. But what's even better is the seafood pancake. Just the right balance of pancake with seafood. 

There was only one guy working the front for the whole place, so we had to keep stopping him and asking him for more tea and water, but we were also there late, so we understood. 

It's in the Safeway shopping center, so parking was free and easy because we were there late. 

The ban-chan (sp?) was a little skimpy for two people (i saw the table next to us only order for one, and got the same amount that we had). 

But this is still a solid late night food joint.
author: Vicky L.

description:
This is my Korean go-to in the Fillmore area. Casual Korean food, I usually rotated between dol sot bi bim bap, soon tofu soup and omurice (not sure if there was any Korean take?). The quality of food and service might vary depending on the time of day and how busy they were, as I had various experiences with the same dishes. Also it was sort of random whether there would be barley tea and soup. Most of the time they had banchan with several small appetizers on the same plate.

I frequented this place a lot more than other Korean restaurants in the area because it was reasonably priced, not overly packed, and I had enjoyed the food every time despite some slight variations. Definitely returning for my next Korean food crave :P
author: Jaclyn C.

description: We were looking for an interesting place to eat and wandered in here. The waitress was rude, and a horsefly climbed all over my mothers neck. The bathrooms are dirty and the miso soup we drank before leaving was mediocre at best.
author: Becky D.

description: We came here for a quick bite before heading to a show at The Fillmore (because it's literally right down the street,) and I was pleasantly surprised! The food was delicious.. I got the BBQ Beef Box and it was the perfect portion! My boyfriend got the Beef Plate, which was the perfect amount for him. Highly recommend & will go again if I'm ever in the area!
author: Heather G.

description:
Having just moved to San Francisco from Seoul, my partner and I were craving some Korean food.  The restaurant is small and clean.   The waitress was kind and attentive.   That said, the menu is quite extensive.    

I settled for the kimchi soup.  It comes with a side of rice.   The soup was good.  One word which describes the taste would be sweet.   I was surprised since most  is not.   I think it sweet was because the pork was marinated.   That said, overall it was good.    

My partner had the bibimbap.  It was good, but again it was sweet.   Also, the beef which was included was more of a sweet teriyaki.   Not bad, just different.    

Of course there was ban-chan.   The kimchi was decent.   

Overall, for your simple Korean staples, we enjoyed the food.
author: William G.

description: It's a little bit overpriced, but the portion sizes are reasonable, seating is quick, and the staff is incredibly efficient about preparing orders quickly. My friends and I really enjoyed the seafood pancake, bibimbap, and seafood tofu soup and appreciated the clear plastic take home containers they had for us (versus white styrofoam common at other places).
author: Stephanie G.

description: One of my work lunchtime spots - whether I'm eating solo or with a small group of friends - food is always consistently good, friendly service, and good prices. They have lunch plates, but I usually order a la carte so I have some leftovers to take home. Space is cozy and comfortable. I love their barley(?) tea too.
author: Elaine W.

description:
The roommate and I have been on a Korean drama kick. Naturally, after watching people eat Korean food, I was craving it! We ordered delivery on Monday, July 4th for dinner through DoorDash. We placed the order at 7:15pm and it arrived at 7:50pm. I live in Outer Richmond.

53. BBQ Short Rib Plate: Grilled short ribs marinated in house special sauce ($26.95)
57. Pork Plate: Spicy, Grilled thin-sliced pork marinated in a spicy sauce ($16.95)
77. Bibim Neng Myon: Spicy, Cold buckwheat noodles mixed with hot sauce ($11.95)
82. Bone Soup with Potato: Spicy, Pork ribs and potato stewed with mixed vegetables in spicy sauce ($15.95 for one serving)

I ordered the kalbi. The meat had great flavor. Smokey, savory, with a hint of sweetness. The pork was okay. It wasn't spicy at all and I thought it was a little mushy. The cold noodles were okay, but overly sauced. And I love sauce. The roommate added some soup to thin it out, but it was still too saucy. The soup was okay. Not much complexity in flavors. It just tasted mostly like bean paste.

Other than the galbi, everything else was just okay. We did get three containers with rice and side dishes: napa cabbage kimchee, daikon kimchi, potato salad, and fish cake. I kind of wish they provided a couple more side dishes as four isn't really a lot. Three stars overall.
author: Elena N.

description: Best late night good in the neighborhood. I get off work at just before midnight around here and i usually go here to fill up before heading home. The food is traditional and satisfying, the side dishes are delicious, and the booze is cheap. Note that last call for food tends to be around 1.
author: Colin T.

description: Been going here since like 2000 and it's still great! The only thing I ever order is the Seafood Bi Bim Bap and compared to most restaurants I go to, the price never got insanely high like most of my favorite restaurants. I was here recently and was surprised there was no customers there but us. This place deserves way more business!
author: B-Rai B.

description: So yummy hmm can't stop eating.. what a great day with great restaurant .. kimuchi soup is so so delicious.. don't forget to try when you here ;)
author: Zaw Win T.

description: Came here for lunch and ordered a bbq beef lunch combo ($11). Generous serving of flavorful marinated beef. The rice was kinda stale and the tofu in the miso soup tasted expired. Small banchan and barley tea provided. Came here around 2pm and we were able to walk in and get a table right away. I would say it's an adequate place for Korean food for lunch.
author: Thomas L.

description: Been here once before with no issue but I don't remember how the food was before...  this time however I ordered the tempura dinner box.  Big mistake.  It was the worst tempura I have ever had.  The crust was SO HARD.  It would have been better suited on some fried chicken but even that I am not sure about.  The little plates were fine.  Had some of the dol sat bibimbop and it was ok.  Service was slow.  Free green tea but it took forever for a refill.
author: Hello.kitty.kat S.

description: Came here for a quick lunch after getting my China Visa a few blocks away. I use to come here during my college years and loved the Korean food here. After not visiting for a few years, I think there food quality went down. I didn't like my spicy rice cake. I taste the spice but not enough flavoring. Their rice tea still taste the same. The interior is very old. There are hole in some of the benches. The waitress was very nice, Always refilling my water and checking up on me. I probably won't be coming back here for some time.
author: Sandy A.

description: I've ordered delivery several times through DoorDash in the past few weeks. The food is quite good!  I've tried chol myun (spicy noodle) - yum. Think it would've been better if there were more cucumber in the noodle dish. Spicy bbq pork -- really good!  I will order that again. And beef/kalbi soup - also yummy. I have to say, the food is better than some of the Korean restaurants in the area.
author: Esther L.

description: The kimchi pork stew is delicious and it also comes with a side a rice. It's not too spicy but still really good. Also had the rice cakes, they're really good but next time I'll order it with dry noodles because there's a lot of sauce left over.
author: Irene R.

description: It's in very poor taste to come here and hear the "N" word casually play on the radio  - of course when you call to complain, no one can speak a word of english but when you wave $20.00 or a Amex card in someone's face they sound very american.... umhmmm...  good bi bim bop though..
author: Dallas S.

description: Everything had amazing flavor, and the pork hocks(pettitoes) is nothing comparable! Had to-go for my home party, and Hands down amazing!!
author: HJ P.

description: I was out for a late night stroll very hungry after midnight looking for good food. The menu was excellent the rib soup divine the service what is superb the waitress had a great smile I'm fully delighted and think this is highly recommended
author: Robert G.

description:
I came here last night for dinner, and am I glad I did. Never heard of it, but decided to give it a try. The BBQ is good, and you don't have to wait in some crazy long line. However, the BBQ is just as expensive as it is at any Korean place in the city. I got the short ribs or kalbi, and man was it delicious. The portion seemed a bit smaller than what I'm used to though. I was still hungry for more in the end. I also got the spicy chicken, and that was alright. Maybe I'm just a beef type of person. 

The banchan choices are limited and ok, but my main thing is the dinner entrees anyway. Good food,  fast-and-friendly service, and no wait time. Perfect for when you just want to eat what you crave without all the hype and crowds, but having the food be just as good.
author: Stacey L.

description: Ordered kimchi fried rice from them, and it was OK. They did get my food ready very quick though. It's a little bit hard to find using my phone, but well, I guess it's not their fault. There's plenty of parking near by, which is a huge plus!
author: Edward M.

description: Love this place. It is a neighborhood staple for a casual last-minute bite that never disappoints.
author: Frances A.

description:
A more traditional restaurant hidden among hipster gastro pubs. The food is very flavorful but unfortunately squid is too chewy and almost impossible to eat. We loved the seafood pancake so much that it compensated for the rest :). We had seafood tofu soup and octopus with spicy udon which was great.

A hidden gem in the neighborhood for sure!
author: Anat N.

description:
This is a great place for traditional Korea food. It was an amazing. I ordered BBQ short rib (Kalbi) and It was a pretty good. I highly recommended this place for lunch and dinner.  

Good Service which I really appreciated! Staff was very friendly to us. All the servers were super nice and checked up on us often.
author: Tanpan M.

description:
My group and i  went there recently, food and service was really good , i had beef tofu soup really yumm... 
I would highly suggest you to go there ;)
author: Bat Erdene T.

description:
Eats: I visited this restaurant a couple times and have tried 5-6 items from the menu so far. Most of them were above average, but the highlight was pointing to the Dol sot Bi Bim Bap and Assorted Meat Variety which were flavorful. They were really good for the cold weather in San Francisco to keep you stay warm.
Staffs: Waitresses friendly with courtesy service. Both of them kept checking back on foods and refill my hot tea.
This place just becomes my favorite spot on Fillmore.
author: Yokiiez T.

description:
This place is my go to eat-alone meal. The dinner combo is slightly pricey considering there's AYCE across the street. 

HOWEVER, the marinade on their galbi is unparalleled. The japchae side dish is a hit or miss -- sometimes it's cold and clumpy, but if you order the entree, the ratios of the ingredients will be good.

If you eat very little and break a dish out into several meals, this place is worth it. If you're famished, I'd say it's better spent going to AYCE at Beque or YakiniQ though the marinade isn't as good as here...but the tradeoff of quantity is worth it depending on your mood.
author: Vi T.

description:
Traditional Korean restaurant tucked away in a shopping plaza. It was kind of hard for me to find it at first but just turn the corner after you pass Subway. The prices were reasonable and the service was really friendly.

I loved their free brown rice tea which the waitress kindly kept refilling for us. The banchan was good, I enjoyed the potato salad and fish cake.

My friend and I each got the dolsot (stone pot) bibimbap for $13. It was filled with delicious rice and vegetables and you can add as much spicy sauce to it as you want. As far as bibimbap goes it was definitely better than average. I would be back here again if I'm craving Korean food!
author: Linda X.

description:
I JUST HAD THE BEST BIBIMBAP here. It was so good that I almost burned my mouth because I was eating too fast. Definitely order Dolsot Kimchee Bibimbap, if you like spicy food!

I came here on multiple occasions, All the Korean dishes are usually pretty good! Only complaint was that Hamburger steak portion is kind of small, so you would still be hungry. 

I just wish they had a tad better service, especially during late night. 

Can't wait to try more dishes here. I will be back for my Korean food cravings!
author: Solongo B.

description: Cozy, yummy, good service.  They don't overcook their BBQ (thank God! LOL).  Pretty extensive menu for such a small place.
author: Ania B.

description:
My friend suggested Arang while we were in the Fillmore district in a time crunch.  I had doubts knowing that Korean sit down restaurants are not usually quick.  My friend liked Arang for their bibimbap, and I wish I ordered that as well. 

The lunch special menu provided many options, and I ordered the spicy beef stew, with crunchy potstickers.  Our server provided water, hot tea, and many of the Korean BBQ side dishes (kimchi, bean sprouts, rice cakes,  etc.).  

The stew tasted ok, nothing a little soy sauce and hot sauce couldn't fix.   The side dishes were tasty, and the service was good.  I'd drop in again to try something else, and think the prices are reasonable.
author: Marlon T.

description:
Tonight I ordered the stir fry kimchi and tofu with pork dish to go, and when I got home, there was NO pork!! Me and my bf were really upset because this is the second time that the cook made this mistake. The first time wasnt as upsetting as this time because this time we went home and had to drive back after we called them and told them they forgot the pork. So when my bf went in there, he was just expecting a small portion of meat that was originally supposed to go with our order. To our surprise, the cook actually came out of the kitchen and apologized to my bf for his mistake. And instead of giving us the normal portion of meat, the cook gave us a larger portion of meat and was extremely apologetic for his mistake. As upset as we were, the cook's apology and make up gesture actually made us very happy. When we got home we enjoyed our meal and felt really good about it :) 



My usual here is the stir fried kimchi pork and tofu, military soup and kimchi fried rice with no corn. The kimchi fried rice is really good, but their portion is pretty small :/ The sea bass soup is pretty decent as well, a lot of flavor and not too fishy. The great part about this restaurant is that they're open til 2am everyday!
 
This is a good place to grab some good Korean food if your ever in Jtown!
author: Amanda R.

description:
This review is for a takeout order of kimchi fried rice and japchae. 

Before moving away from SF, I frequented Arang regularly because of their phenomenal kimchi fried rice. It was spicy with a strong kimchi flavor and generous amounts of meat. Over the past few years, during visits, I still went to Arang for the kimchi fried rice. 

I am sad to report that I picked up two orders of kimchi fried rice yesterday, and both orders were underwhelming. In fact, I could barely taste the kimchi and it was not spicy at all. I also ordered japchae, which was lacking in flavor. I don't know if they changed recipes, or chefs, but the kimchi fried rice of recent is nowhere as good as it used to be. 

Two stars for easy phone ordering and friendly staff (as usual).
author: Cora L.

description:
It's open till 2am so what can you say? It definitely satisfies the need for late night Korean food. The service was alright. I went with friends and everyone was halfway through their meal before I got my dukbokki. (Luckily I could mooch off my friends or else I'd complain more!) 

The food is definitely good though! The dukbokki was chewy and bouncy with really good flavor. Also the fried chicken is super crispy and delicious! The staple tofu soup, bibimbap, and seafood pancakes were also good! 

Parking is super easy since you can park in the Safeway plaza (on Webster).
author: Kelly N.

description: Not bad for a korean restaurant in San Francisco, I had the boodae chigae and they put baked beans in it.  Probably the best in town.  Very cozy environment and great place to grab a drink with a friend.
author: James C.

description: Sooooo good. I love how much food you get for such a great price in the city. My meal came out quickly and they gave me free miso soup while I waited. It's not upscale, definitely a Ma and Pa place. I don't mind that.
author: Laurina S.

description:
Arang has this home-y vibe of being tucked away on the corner. You really feel like you're away from the outside world since you can't really see the door from the tables and I think the windows are all covered up if there are even any. Maybe that would be bad if you were claustrophobic... but to me, it feels just like being back in Korea where most of the restaurants are sometimes tucked underground and away from the noise of the outside streets.

We got the back booth as a group of 5 on a Friday night. The server was really courteous and understanding when we needed more time to decide. You get barley tea and a small tray of side dishes. In the background, they are playing a mix of recent K-pop songs and Top 40 mainstream. 

Food here is amazing! I'm so happy that the food hasn't changed and possibly, may have gotten even better? It's been awhile so I can't remember but I also ordered new dishes this time.

KIMCHI FRIED RICE - 3.5/5 Delicious but pretty standard. Came with a fried egg on top and the spam is really addicting. Wasn't super spicy so there wasn't really a strong kimchi taste but I enjoyed it since it was flavorful and I just love spam. 

BBQ PORK BULGOGI BENTO - 4/5 I was supposed to order the plate but I think I accidentally pointed to a bento. But the bento came with a decent amount of pork so it was all good. There was also 2 fried dumplings, salad and white rice as well as these potato tasting strips. Pork was really good and not overcooked or overly spicy. 

FRIED CHICKEN WITH SPICY SAUCE - 5/5 I don't know the actual name since we just referred to the picture hanging in the front but this was amazing Korean fried chicken. If only we had some beer to go along with it for chimaek. The chicken was tender and the breading was done so well. It was nice and crispy and just melted in my mouth. The spicy sauce was sooooooo good. I thought SanTung was my favorite for chicken wings but I was wrong. It's Arang. The chicken is also really meaty so you get big pieces! Not some dingy tiny little chicken wing. I think there were about ten pieces given that five of us each ate two wings.

SLICED RICE CAKE STEW - 4/5 We thought it was going to be spicy for some reason but it wasn't... or maybe it was and we couldn't tell since we were using our bowls that had the spicy chicken. It was a white broth and it tasted a bit like seaweed/sesame. I thought it was a nice contrast to all the spicy foods we had earlier. The rice cake was nice and soft but what I really enjoyed was the broth. This may be a good hangover stew. 

Overall, it was a great meal and food + ambiance + service were all around excellent. Prices are around $10-13 for dinner which I find average for Korean food in SF (actually quite cheap since some places can go up to $15...)
author: Diana C.

description:
3- stars for service
5- stars for food

My go-to Korean spot anytime I'm in the area! I've been coming here for years and never disappoints. Sometimes when it's busy staff can be a little slow but usually I have company with me so quality time with friends or family often makes up for it!
author: Sadia B.

description: This is a cleaner somewhat cheaper Korean joint. Food takes forever to be made and service is order, get your food and ask for the check.
author: Liz N.

description:
I am an avid fan of Korean food, Kalbi in particular. For where it's located, I didn't have any high hopes for this establishment to give Korean food justice, but oh boy I was impressed.

They have a variety of selections, both of meat, appetizers, soups and other combinations. I find this place rather cheap in terms of price, comparing it to the other Korean restaurants in San Francisco.

I recommend getting their lunch or dinner boxes that offers, kalbi, bulgogi, chicken teryaki which comes with salad, rice, the side dishes and a couple of gyozas. 

I also suggest trying their yogurt soju that I find to be tasty without being bothered by any bad spirit after taste.
author: Jan R.

description: This place is so good. My favorite is BBQ short Rip it so delicious and I try to Assorted meat variety it very very good. Let check it out :))
author: Chuthamas W.

description:
Nice cozy korea food place with a family-store feel. Usually opens very very late, so it's a great place to get late night K-food especially when you are in J-town!

The "korean starter snacks" they give you is served on a plastic "lunchables" case, which just goes to show how mom-and-pops this place is! The inside is actually not very big, but has a very warm feel to it.

In terms of customers, there are definitely lots of customers even late into the night. About half the tables have the "reserved" sign on it, and when I was eating I saw a couple of customers come in who were put into those tables, so I know there are definitely tables being reserved.

Most customers ordered big giant "hotpot" style dishes to share between a group. I got the korean tofu soup, which was ok. There was tons of tofu, but not really much meat, which was disappointing. The starter snacks was really tasty though.

Would definitely stop by again when I am in the area.
author: Henry L.

description:
Definitely have had better.

I had kimchi bokkumbab and kimchi jigae ()
both were just soso. the soup was overcooked with a thin 
taste, and lacking some of the usual ingredients.

All the workers were Thai. Regardless of the workers ethnicity,
they should know how to make the food they sell.

Go to 707 sutter, or yakiniq over this place.  
I lived in korea almost 2 years, this falls really short.
author: Ethan C.

description:
This place is awesome.  Especially kimchi soup really tasty also people there so nice. 

Pretty authentic Korean food and perferct for group drinking at late night.
author: Pla K.

description:
This little gem is tucked in Japantown.  Took us a few minutes to find the place, since it's located not right on Fillmore but around the corner in the courtyard plaza.

We ordered 3 BBQs, seafood pancake, rice cake, japchae, gyoza and bibimbap for 6 people and we were stuffed with 3 boxes of left over.  All the dishes were reasonably priced and cheaper than most Korean restaurants in the area.  The flavors were on key, ingredients were fresh and service was great. 

Check it out!  You won't be disappointed.  

Now I'm hungry....
author: C L.

description: I had a lunch at Arang restaurant today and Kimchi Dol Sot Bibimbap was super delicious. Great service, fast and nice environment. Thanks
author: Oyuntsetseg T.

description:
I always get "Kimchee Dol sot bibimbap" This is the best dish ever i had it like a 100times. you should try once!!!.also i love "Tok Bok Gi" the marinated rice sticks is PERFECTLY AWESOME!!! Im Lovin it
Dont forget to try "Fried chicken in spicy special sauce" crispy yummy hmmmm i bet you would come back for it again and again 
give them 5stars for Foods,Services,Servers,Places and everything lol
author: Piangporn T.

description:
Good music, good service, good food. Took a star off due to not so good sundubu (soondubu). Tasted like boiled water, no salt or anything. 
Dolsot bibimbap and spicy pork plate were 100% though! Would def. come back.
author: Wah W.

description:
this food tastes not that good,also today they charged me 2times and then they force me sign!! I just tell u guys,when they do this ,please be careful!
Come here just waste and cheat u money!
author: Mindy Y.

description: Delicious Korean mussels soup with a good salad and rice. Good music, service and green tea. Open until 2:00 a.m.
author: Gregory K.

description: Great food. Cozy atmosphere. Total hole in the wall with AWESOME food. Love the BIBIMBAP!!
author: Merlino T.

description: We went restaurant last night . I got Assorted meat variety ,it was very taste and delicious.. Recommend should try if you come as a group.Yummy Yummy
author: May H.

description:
I ordered fried chicken (9pieces), I start eating the third one and I found a fly under veggie, I told the waitress and she ask if I want the new one. 10 mins later the new one come with only 5 pieces of chicken and all they burn. It is not new! And where is my another piece?

Goodbye. Will not go back again!
author: Thancha N.

description:
Haven't been back here for 5 years. Are these new owners?
More like already prepared food, then preheat in a microwave.
Our seafood tofu soup was lack of seafood and tasted very watery. And it was only warm enough. Usually this dish should be boiling and sizzling hot. The other seafood stone rice was kind of a mushy, also lack of seafood. Worst of all, no taste. The 2 stars are for the 2 ladies who were running around from the kitchen preparing food and doing their waitressing. Only 2 persons running around the restaurant, no cook? Not coming anymore, not worth it.
author: Judy T.

description:
I came here to escape the crazy lines at the Ramen festival at J-town...Only to find a 45 min wait at Arang. But we waited and finally got a table. The service was not that good, but they only had about 2 waitresses and a ton of customers. I felt bad for the waitresses because they were clearly understaffed at the moment. 
Anyways, onto the food...overall, not very tasty. The bento box with bulgogi wasn't that good. The meat was dry and not flavorful. The bibimbap looked good, but when you taste it, it is pretty bland. The kim chi fried rice didn't taste that great either. It tasted cheaply made with a bunch of ketchup. The only thing I liked was the seafood pancake and the side dishes. The seafood pancake was crispy and flavorful, especially with the dipping sauce. This is probably the only dish I would order again. There are plenty of better Korean restaurants in the city.
author: Jean S.

description: I like the menu here..this place has Japanese and Korean, but they specialize in Korean. Kinda expensive by a dollar or two. I got a chicken teriyaki dinner plate and it was good.
author: Denise C.

description: I have limited lunch hour which is 12:00-1:00, so when I go to Arang, I always order on the way. They never fail my order and it's ready when I get there. Their service is very nice. No complain. :)
author: Joyce P.

description: i like it that place. My favorite is BBQ short rib plate so delicious. And Assorted meat variety yummyyyy. That place very fast and good servered. People is very nice and good recommendation food.
author: Sera E.

description: We ordered the vegetable soup and shrimp omelette rice but the soup was too salty and the rice tasted just ok.
author: Belle T.

description:
-Never too packed
-The food isn't spectacular but it's not bad 
-Satisfies your korean food craving if you're in the area 
-Waitresses are pretty attentive
author: Derrick W.

description: Came here for lunch with a friend over the weekend. I had a bit of trouble finding the restaurant because it's tucked into a corner a little off the street. This place is small and looks pretty authentic but the food was disappointing. There wasn't very much variety to the small dishes that usually come at the beginning of the meal at a Korean restaurant. I got the bibimbap, and the beef was good, but the vegetables were barely flavored at all.  The small bowl of complimentary miso soup was pretty good though, and service was fast.
author: Tiffany P.

description: Food was good! I love Korean places especially the small hole in the wall places. Will come back again. Server was nice. Don't get so thrown off by if it has or doesn't have a grill. The food is still very gewd!
author: S P.

description:
Very nice Korean restaurant.!!

The place was pretty small, but comfortable. Waitresses were very polite and greeted us in Korean(which I love). We got seated and they served us the tea and menus. The tea had some kind of rice in it which I thought was pretty cool.

Whenever I came here with my friends, I ate army soup.(they called assorted variety soup for 2 people). This soup is so.... great! I really recommend if you guys like spicy soup. 

After you guys order Army soup, you guys have to order Soju(korean). The combination between SoJU and Army soup.. is... like... perfect!!! It is beyond description..! wow..

I love Arang..!! See ya!
author: Mindo H.

description:
This restaurant offers delicious food you can't taste anywhere else only here at Arang restaurant.
The food was excellent.
Bi Bim Bap tastes as good as it looks.
The prices are reasonable.

I would say that Arang is possibly a local Korean food gem in town.



Highly recommend it!!!!!!
author: Riga R.

description:
Nothing special
Everything Korean in the bay that's "spicy" somehow tastes like korean instant ramen soup base.
That's how my yukgaejang tasted like.
The galbi tang was nothing special. Maybe too much sesame oil.
author: Heejin L.

description:
Grabbed a quick lunch here. 

Pretty basic restaurant tucked away in a strip mall area. If you are not careful, it is easy to pass it up. 

The food was really good, and perfect portions for lunch. I had to the soft tofu spicy soup. I like the tofu was good, fresh and silken. My one complaint is the egg they put in the soup was not done table side. So it didn't thicken the soup the way I like. 

Other than that it was good. The potato salad was REALLY GOOD !
author: Ashlei T.

description: Three stars- this is a good place for convenience if most places are closed and you want a basic dish, but I opted for the kalbi tang (soup) and it was just okay though overpriced. It's pretty quiet inside and they have options under $12 if you are eating on a budget, but it's definitely not LA quality or something to go out of your way for. Not a lot of great asian options near Japantown regardless, but here is another option among the mediocre.
author: Nancy W.

description: Pretty good. Not so great actually, but there's no other places better than here in SF, uf you want to have real Korean style food. I recommand tofu soup and Naengedoenjang soul.
author: Sunguk M.

description:
This place is doing something right--it's been here since my raving days in high school, which was more than 15 years ago!

Arang is a small Korean restaurant next to a karaoke lounge in the Fillmore. The neighborhood may seem a little seedy and the restaurant is small. There are maybe three or four booths towards the back, so it is possible to dine in with a small group of friends, but it will cause you to wait a awhile with such lack of space.

Once you sit down though and start eating, you'll probably forget the earlier woes--the food is really delicious. Their barbeque beef (bulgogi) has been consistently good after all these years I've been there. Service is average--it doesn't take too much effort to flag down a waiter/waitress due to the size.

This place closes at 2 AM in the morning as of this review, so if late night snacking is your fancy, this place will hit the spot. Just be mindful of the karaoke and other crowds during that time and you should be fine.
author: Henry N.

description:
Restaurant is in a corner in the plaza. Just FYI lol. 

The spicy dokboki (rice cakes) with jul myun ( chewy noodles ) is sooo good and unbelievably big. The portion can prob fill me and two of my friends.
- so much rice cakes. I love that. Usually, I find that Korean restaurants skim on the rice cakes and add tons of veggies. Not this place. 

Bibimpap- pretty average in size and is meh. 

Just get the dokboki with jul myun!
*prices are average to me. Not cheap like others have said lol
author: Mel T.

description:
I would give 5 stars for their food and the service!
I had a galbi plate here last Thursday night.
The food was really good, and the server provided an excellent service. (always making sure if we need something else) Both of my friend and I enjoyed our dinner here. I recommend this place.
author: Jessica M.

description:
New owner! 
But the food tastes still the same !

Big soup is always been MUST to get if there are big group of people wanting some soup. Kalbi box for lunch time totally worth it! You have to get it ! Only down part is that there is NO side dishes for boxes :( But it is already cheap .. so no complains ..
author: Yumi K.

description:
Simple, delicious, and filling Korean comfort food. 

I had the tofu Soon Dubu. It definitely hit the spot. My boyfriend had the Dolsot Bibimbop. Also delicious. 

The staff is nice and friendly. Service was pretty quick and the price was good.
author: Melissa T.

description: This place is incredible! Get the Budae Jigae and the Bim Bim Bop with beef. Seafood is also great! I always go here with friends that visit from out of town. I recently took 15 friends there and all were highly impressed. The staff was also very accommodating helping us make one large table to seat everyone. The owners and staff are Korean, most of everyone eating there is Korean, and there is Korean pop music in the background.  I recommend this place to anyone looking for authentic Korean bbq.
author: Joshua G.

description: I came here after a reunion my college friends and I had at a nearby restaurant bar called Pa'ina Lounge. We were hungry and wanted something cheap/good so stumbled into Arang Restaurant. While Arang was cheap, the food really wasn't that good and the service was kind of poor. I guess I am not surprised that this place has 3.5 stars. This place is sort of hard to find since it's around the corner and not directly on Fillmore St. I don't recommend coming here unless you're really in a rut for some food, don't want to venture anywhere else, and don't mind spending more money than you should on Korean food.
author: Marlon T.

description:
It's my first option to grab food whenever i am hungry and don't want to drive or take a bus. I live across the street at Fillmore Center and my place is surrounded by a lot of restaurants, starbucks and fast foods. But as an asian, i always want to grab something with rice whenever i am super hungry. Arang served good lunch box and dinner box, but i prefer to have it for lunch and order other menu for dinner.

For the box, their spicy pork or bbq pork they called it, is a really good deal. It has two gyoza, salad, japchae, rice and they also give you miso soup on the side. If you want other than pork, their galbi lunch box is also good as well.

For dinner, the rapokki is really good. It is a rice cakes with ramen and a bit spicy, sometimes it comes with fish cakes and sometimes not. Their casserole is also good and big, although it meant to be for two people, but i think you can feed three people with that. Their fried chicken is also good, but it takes a bit long to fry it. So you have to be patient a bit for that.

The service is really good as well. The staffs are friendly. 

Just one thing , if i may say to improve, the rest room need more cleaning :)

But other than that, i love arang :))))
author: Ulrica J.

description:
I took my friend to this place for a late dinner on Wednesday. I tried the Kalbi, bulgogi, and seafood pancake. They all taste good! They are my favorite. The place is not that big but it's pretty clean, and it was a very short wait. I've been coming to this place for few years already, and I'm rarely disappointed. 
Everything here is at least 4/5 stars such as food and cleanliness, and 5/5 stars includes great service :)
author: Adrianne T.

description: Can't believe I've never written a review for Arang. They are my favorite korean restaurant in SF! It's not even close! I've been going there for many years, and they have the best korean foods, prices and staff. My favorites are kalbi box (which comes with jap chae, mandoo and other stuff), their many soups and seafood pancake. Their cut of meat is solid. They take pride in making their dishes healthy and food is not "greasy" like at some places. If you are looking to bbq at the table, this place doesn't have that. But, I'd rather the experts cook it deliciously in the kitchen, and I can entertain friends anyway. I've had them cater parties, and they always work with me to get a tasty menu together. It makes me hungry to write this review!
author: jey o.

description: I thought it was funny how their banchan came out on one plate.  Overall, not a bad place.  It fixed my craving because i was starving on new years day and after going to 3 places this was the only one that was open.  Their Kalbi dinner meal was a good deal and there wasn't really much to complain about, other than one fly that was flying around the restaurant.
author: Anthony C.

description:
Best Kimchi Fried Rice in San Francisco! BBQ plates, Kalbi Tang and Army base stew are good too. 
Bibimbap is just soso, Fried chick is too oily for me, but my friend really likes it.
author: Rosalind D.

description:
Small Korean food joint. They got meals to snacks & booze.

Foods are good, nice workers, cheap, and opens late. What's not to like about this place? Been going here since 2012 and still like it.

If you live near Fillmore and craving some Korean food, check this place out. I suggest Dol Sot Bibimbob series.
author: Brandon K.

description:
I loved they Seafood Dol Sot Bi Bim Bup, it's my favorite dish ever :) 

You should try Pork Feet, Kimchi Pancake and BBQ short rib with Soju it's such a perfect together.
author: FromSky N.

description: Food was well prepared. One of the decent Korean restaurants in SF. Service was attentive and professional.
author: 雪峰

description: Came here after a concert at The Independent and got some budae jeongal with my friend! Yum! Definitely hit the spot!!! Two tired, hungry girls walked out of here satisfied and happy!
author: Kim N.

description:
Food: Lacking the major components in Korean food. The kimchi fried rice was tasteless, oily, and greasy. The fried chicken was too oily. 

Decor: Very old and like an old office. 

Service was okay but not even enough to compensate the food. 

Just a giant NO. Do yourself a favor and eat somewhere else.
author: Jane W.

description:
"Dude, you haven't reviewed any Korean places in a while...what's up with that?"  What's up with that indeed...I guess it really has been a while!

Although it doesn't look all that impressive (and has an odd layout to boot), I like that Arang is such a small and simple place.  In a way, it's almost like a diner - come in, get something to eat, go.  Well, except that it's better since they have Korean food and they play K-pop (makes it taste that much more authentic!), but you get my drift.

The menu is extensive, filled with the usual staples (bibimbap, BBQ meat platters, haemul pajun/seafood pancake, soups/stews), along side a number of more unique dishes and a handful of Japanese items (oddly enough).  Of the things I've tried though, my favorite of the bunch is easily their Kimchee and Sausage Jeongol - meat and ramen stew/casserole.  Although they don't do it as well as my favorite place in Oakland (sahn Maru), it's plenty good regardless.  Loaded with ramen noodles, spam, hot dog, sliced rice cake, and kimchee in a spicy kimchee soup, we're talking about a whole lotta goodness going on.  Granted, it's on the salty side like how most Korean soups/stews are, but it packs a ton of flavor and spice.  The best part is that you can order an individual portion in a bowl, or go with a large pot of it that sits on a burner for the table to share.  Woohoo!

Beyond that, the other dishes I've tried have all been pretty decent.  One of my friends likes their kimchee fried rice, and their japchae and haemul pajun are good.  The BBQ meats are solid and will hit the spot if you have a craving, but they obviously can't compare to actual Korean BBQ joints.  Their ban chan offerings, on the other hand, leave a bit to be desired.  They only offer four or five for the table, and even then the taste is just "meh" (at least the kimchee still tastes okay).  

Also, one last note that's not really specific to Arang, but about the parking lot for the complex - be VERY careful about how long you leave your car there for.  Make sure you check the signs for the posted limit because the Safeway/property manager will tow your car, especially if there are events going on at the Fillmore or Yoshi's.  Believe me...I know...
author: Mike L.

description: I love this place! Especially there kimchi!!! It tastes like my mother's kimchi that used to make for when i was young. The people are really nice and friendly.
author: Munkhuu N.

description: Their casserole dish is really good. It has a lot of portion. Their service is very good as well. The price is pretty affordable as well! I came with a group of eight but they served us graciously.
author: Nasan E.

description: The food is so good and they are very nice! I either get the bibimbap or the dinner combo. It is well worth the price. I recommend going here before or after karaoke. They also have fast service.
author: Marisa L.

description: The search for decent Korean food in the Bay Area hit a positive note with Arang Restaurant. The banchan (assorted appetizers) was awesome. The Dol Sot Bi Bim Bap was large, packed with meat, and provided a pleasant mix of different flavors. And to top it all off, prices are reasonable, service is friendly, it's open until 2 AM (in SF - the city that goes to sleep at 10 PM), and parking is easy since you can park in the Safeway parking lot.
author: Mark C.

description:
This used to be our neighborhood go-to spot. Super convenient that they're open until 2am. It's pretty hard to get a seat here at lunch, surprisingly. I wish they'd just drop the "Japanese" part of their menu--they're removed enough from Japantown proper that I don't feel like they need it. Service is good--there used to be a super nice lady who worked there who was very attentive, but she disappeared all of a sudden a little over a year ago. 

Anyways, on to the food. Our standard was a spicy pork or spicy chicken plate and a labokgi (ramen with rice cakes in spicy sauce). Alternatively the kimchi pancakes and soondubu were okay. Soju cocktail is reasonable as well. 

I would say don't go for the bone soups because they're honestly pretty bland. 

Sadly before we moved away the quality seemed to go down a bit--rice cakes would get overcooked..sauce wasn't spicy enough..but fingers crossed next time we go back for nostalgia they'll be back to normal.
author: Vivian C.

description:
I liked this place because it isn't one of the many places in SF where you have to wait in line.

-Seated immediately
-Decent food
-Large variety 
-I would go again
author: Marina S.

description: Sweet and lovely  place. Love the bibimbap and the rest of the food menu are fantastic dcishes.Waiting  staff  are  efficient  and great  people.
author: Adrian S.

description:
My favorite korean restaurant in sf!! 
The place is small but nice interior and comfortable. The waitress and waiters are very friendly. 
You have to try dol sot bibimbab and kimchi soup! These are my favorite!!
Overall every food was excellent.
author: Eunice C.

description: I love this place.. Great portion n price..great lunch menu..!! Now I'm tempted to go eat later hahaha..
author: Crisy G.

description:
I believe I've been here a good 7 years ago. That was before my days of Yelping and well I don't have a very good memory.

This place is very hard to find but if you love Korean food you would love it here. We arrived around 8:45pm and the place was still pretty empty. Upon our arrival entire groups started coming in.

My friend who frequents here often says their prices has gone up. Can't get anything without having to pay at least $13-14. This includes tax and tip. 

All of us ordered the Short Ribs Dinner Box special for $12. It was a good amount of food. If you aren't a big eater then you should share this. Comes with gyoza (small but tasty), salad (doesn't feel Korean to me and eh), shredded potato (overly salty), vermicelli noodles (not bad). The short ribs were very tasty and they give you a good amount. Rice is good too. 

One bathroom.

I wouldn't mind coming back.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I usually come here either for take out when too lazy to cook something at home, or at 1 AM when the drunk munchies kick in. There is nothing better then a Kimchi Bibimbap on a vodka filled stomach. It's been the best hang over preventer yet!

All in all, the food has been great, and service is good enough for me.
author: Daniel G.

description:
Awful service. Had to get my own napkins. Had to request to refill my tea. Had to ask for more spoons, bowls...bottom line not enough utensils for 4 adults and a toddler.  Food was not good. Do not order galbi - it's dry and chewy. Soondubu is bland. Ban chan are all thrown together on a plate. Portions were small. We were still hungry. Check was added up wrong. Charged gratuity of 18% without letting customers know. Reports it's the law to charge 18% gratuity - highly doubtful since tipping is base on service. What service???

Would have given no tip if I could. Thankful my kid made a mess.
author: Julie H.

description: While service is often slow and they occasionally forget things off your plate, they always make it right and always friendly. The food is always good and piping hot. Some of my faves: soft tofu soup, short rib soup with tam noodles and their pancake.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Food is mediocre.  Service is great however.  They don't close until really late.  Good place for Korean at late in the night.  Definitely can find better place in regular hours.  O skip their Korean Sausage.  Not good at all compare to others found in San Jose or LA.
author: Jun X.

description: Food wss meh. Too salty. Service was meh. I came here today during lunch, the waiter was rude   I dont think ill come back here
author: Javier G.

description:
Came here for a group lunch and was pretty satisfied.

The waitress was nice and the food came pretty fast. This place had music, mirrors, and pretty lantern lights. Its also a very small place. The restaurant is literally just a door next to a karaoke place.

I ordered the soon tofu soup and it was really spicy! So if you want spicy, but not too spicy, ask them to go lite on the spicy ness. My friend got the deokbokki with ramen. When tht dish came, I was shocked by how big her plate was and how yummy it looked!!! They also serve bento boxes and miso with any rice dishes.

Their water tastes BAD. So bring your own water or order a beverage.

The music played there was nice, some oldies and some new . It just lightened up my mood! 

I love yellow radish, so I asked for a side order of it and it came right away! Usually korean restaurants charge us for asking for extra so I was very pleased with that.

Unlike other Korean restaurants that Ive been to, this was the first to have omelettes!!! Although I did not get to try it, Id try it if I ever come back.
author: Josie D.

description:
Arang doesn't need to be crazy good or crazy bad to stay in my mind - it's always there, like these 3 stars are always there. I consider this place an all-arounder, a standby.

I like Arang for the sujebi, bibim naengmyeon, and other dishes I can't necessarily get everywhere. I probably would like them for the haejangguk, but I noticed theirs doesn't have blood. Y'all, I neeeed blooooodd.

They have chicken gizzards(!). Now they just need livers, hearts, and whatever that giblet was that I used to pluck from the KFC thighs back in the day.

There are a couple of menu items with spam, for my spam friends and mahalo friends.

There can be a 20-30 minute wait if it's crowded, but they let you browse the menu while standing in line.

When you read the menu, text me if they've added other chicken organs.
author: Dan B.

description:
I really only came here to try to the Korean version of shaved ice (patbingsu) so it might not be fair to rate the entire restaurant.

I've never had Korean shaved ice before so didn't know what to expect. The shaved ice comes with a scoop of vanilla ice cream, red beans, slices of banana, cinnamon toast crunch, and other goodies. It's also gigantic. Definitely recommend sharing. I liked the crunchiness of the cinnamon toast cereal but am undecided on the combination of ice cream and shaved ice. It's a little weird to me to have ice on ice cream. It just dilutes the ice cream creaminess to watery.
author: Jean K.

description:
The food's okay.. I either enjoy my korean food super clean or just 'dirty' haha but this place is very in-between. There could be more variety of side dishes too, but I like that they have a variety of choices. 

Here is where I was confused by the waiter. My brother and I were midway through our meal when my mom joined us and ordered her food. I also notice couple people coming in and asking the waiter if they can seat 8 people in about 30 minutes or so. Anyways, while my mom is clearly still eating, he comes by and tells us that we have about 5- 10 minutes to finish our food. He proceeds to say its because he has 8 people to seat soon (actually in a pretty rude standoff-ish tone), but I answered back .."she's not even halfway done with her food.." He then says, "I know, thats why I gave you 10 minutes. I think that's plenty." I asked "so ..you're telling us to leave while we're still eating... are we not customers ourselves?.... that's odd. " 

he had nothing to say and turned back around, but obviously that interaction made me not wanna be there - also making my mom rush through her meal which was so unnecessary. 

It's fine when the restaurant gets too crowded and we're DONE eating to come ask us to possibly take off. As considerate people, we'd get up quickly and get going if that was the situation. 

I just think it's so rude to ask a customer to finish ASAP when they're mid-eating... - aren't those basics? my mom already eats pretty quick, don't rush her.  just sayin.
author: Dina K.

description:
Arang disappointed. after handing me a menu that included lunch specials, the waitress said i had to order from the dinner menu. (silly me, trying to figure what to eat and not reading the small print.)

eats: dolsut bibimbap10.95)
-miso soup: strong tofu taste, kind of strange
-7ish banchan (3 tofu), mostly referigator cold and tasteless
-barley popcorn tea: very good, never refilled..
-stoneware very hot, rice barely seared. no crusted rice
-toppings of fried egg, marinated beef, carrot, spinach, bean sprouts.
-only taste came from hot sauce which i added to mix.

banchan:
-one waitress on duty
-except for the tea,  warm rice and tasty beef, food disappointed.
-definitely not returning.
-seating for only 30ish people.
author: Victor G.

description: Its really great for late night food! Right by the Shopping Plaza in Japantown so parking is super easy. Prices is reasonable and service is really good too.
author: Cavin T.

description: Food was mediocre. Nothing too special. Will give them another try to make sure my review isn't bias. Update: To be continue
author: Rick H.

description:
Their Bulgogi Dinner Box is delicious! It was $10.95, which is a pretty good price for a Korean BBQ dinner. The service was good and the free tea was really good as well.

Now I know where to go when I need me some Korean food!
author: Phillip K.

description: Kalbi tang. Priceless super home cook meal taste. Feels like I'm at my aunties house. Cucumber kimchi soooo good! Simple good home made taste
author: Izzy B.

description:
Definitely thought this place was called Karang. 

They don't have those 50 little plates of Korean appetizers here! I usually wouldn't care but I was starving. Luckily the food came out quick and the portions were huge. The served me the biggest salmon fillet of my life. It looked like a brick. On closer inspection I noticed it was a piece of salmon folded over. I got the salmon teriyaki box that I keep wanting to call a bento box. Am I allowed to call it a bento box if its Korean? Someone fill me in on being Asian. 

We were only here because my friend was trynna illegally park in the parking lot while we went to look for restaurants and we walked by here and apparently anything over 3 stars is good enough for him so I followed him in. Its located in a really bizarre looking strip mall that I've never seen in my life. I did not feel like I was in San Francisco anymore and instead thought I was back in Koreatown in LA.
author: Tiffany V.

description: One of my favorite. Affordable, always good service and good portion of food. Sometimes music is little too loud but you can always ask them to lower it down.
author: Togi S.

description:
We've been getting takeout from here pretty regularly for a couple years now. We love their short rib combination, seafood bibimbap, and seafood scallion pancake, but haven't really tried much else (we know what we like, kinda boring, I know).

The restaurant itself is a bit small so sometimes you have to wait if you want a table. Also, for some reason there's a lot of wait staff turnover, so you don't really get treated like a regular here even if you are one.
author: T.J. H.

description: I had a dinner with my friends at late night on Friday. We tried their fried chicken, kimchi dolsot, and bbq short ribs. They are all tasty. There were lots of ppl but great service. The servers are friendly and very nice. Strongly recommend here! :)
author: Jang W.

description:
This is an update due to the last 2 times I ate here. 
I came with my son & his girlfriend and ordered the ala carte BBQ spicy pork & beef and the seafood pancake. The beef was definitely NOT grilled, it was cooked in a pan and scooted onto the iron platter, the onions were infinitely not cooked. I asked the waiter if the cook was new/different and he said no, that's how they always cook it. I've eaten here quite a few times and that is not true. The service always sucks here anyway even when they're not busy. When I asked for extra tofu (since we only got 1 piece for 3 people), they said they didn't have any more. Same applied when I asked for more potato salad. $75 for a  1/2 cup of pork &  1/2 cup of beef with maybe $2 worth of ingredients for the seafood pancake is a bit pricey anyway. Tofu & potato salad can't be that expensive. 

The time before I went with my husband and we were the only table that did not get the appetizers before dinner.

I will not be back!
author: May G.

description: The food is generally okay. Bibimpup is too salty. Also Pang Bing Soo desert is just horrible. It is a bad parody on original desert. Wasted money.....
author: P K.

description: I loved this place so much and the people are really nice. There food is really good and you guys wont regret! There kimchi us the best!!
author: Uchka J.

description:
I came here for late night munchies with a couple of my friends and it satisfied our hunger, but the food was only okay.

I ordered a Don Kasu (Deep fried pork) bento box and shared the Korean wonton soup with a friend. 

The Korean wonton soup was BOMB and it was a pretty big bowl! It was warm, flavorful, and so yummy...made me a bit homesick ): It would be perfect for a rainy or cold day! The Don kasu bento box, however, wasn't as good. The meat was dry and hard, just like the rice. I did like the potato shreds though, and the vermicelli and potstickers were nice. But overall, the bento box was decent but I wouldn't come back for it, seeing as the main dish wasn't that good. 

On a side note though, my friend loves ordering delivery from here.
author: Kelly T.

description:
One of my favorite Korean resto in San Francisco. It's small but everything that I've tried on the menu is yummy. It's one of those resto that you can be sure the food always taste good. 

My favorite is their spicy pork, spicy tofu soup, gizzards and the spicy chewy noodles. MMM just thinking about the food makes me hungry :)
author: Arlene R.

description:
I went to Arang twice for dinner and once for late lunch. No self-BBQ so no smoke will get stuck to your clothes! Although I do like that. This place is a little cheaper than some other Korean restaurants in Japantown. 
This place is small so it's not ideal for parties more than 4 or 6. Every time I went, it was pretty busy so be prepared for a little wait.
I like how at night, they play Korean music (largely K-Pop) and during the day they play American music, just so you know~. lol

They give you relatievly the same type of banchan every time. Tofu, eggs, kimchi, bean sprouts, seaweed, etc. The pig feet is great! Get it if you want to try something different. Don't worry, they slice it for you! I didn't like the lamb in the hot pot (for 2 or more) because I hate the way it smells (personal preference). The beef hot pot was like an army stew thing if you know what I mean. If not, please Google it. Didn't give a lot of japchae and my god, that stuff's soooo goooodddd!!!! Bibimnaengmyeon was great as well. ! Even my cousin who sucks at eat spicy foods couldn't get enough of it!  I think pretty much everything is freaking awesome. Haven't tried their sundubu yet though. Their (dol sot) kimchi bibimbap (forgot the shorter version) was great but it was the first time I had it so nothing to compare it to. They do give a lot for bibimbaps. 

Basically can't go wrong with any menu items but I do wish they had a larger menu for soups and the like. They even have soju cocktails but I can't drink those since I'm not yet of age. =(
author: Victoria H.

description: I'm just gonna be straight up, the food sucks. The bibimbap wasn't good compared to other places I've been to. The chili sauce to go with the bibimbap tasted a bit off. While the tofu soup had more items inside, it wasn't as good as bcd or other korean tofu soup places that I've been to. Also, their side dishes were old. I came with friends as a group of 9 people but they split us up into two booths of 4 and 5. We asked them to split our orders to make it easier. They ended up mixing up our dishes and putting it in the wrong booth. They also charged us 18% gratuity when we were separated as a party. Ridiculous.
author: Susan C.

description: My husband and I decided to check out this place since our friend recommended it. We ordered big seafood soup tonight and it was so good that we finished the whole thing. Great service, nice atmosphere, big portions and delicious food. What more could you ask for. Definitely going back again. Heard that bibimbap was really good. Will try next time for sure:)
author: Jackie G.

description:
We found ourselves cruising down Fillmore st. a little after midnight Wednesday and decided to forgo our usual Korean resto, to try out Arang, which is open til 2am. 

Walking in, you'll notice that the crowd is wrinkle-free and I was hit with a realization that I'm no longer a youngin, especially with the cheery K-pop music in the background.

Tea was served immediately upon request.  The menu offers more choices than Won Mi. You can get ramen here if you want or a box dinner (aka Bento Box) for $8.95.  I imagine this place is super popular for lunch as the lunch specials start around $6.

We imbibed on a yougurt soju, a small carafe is $12. It's pleasantly sweet, definitely a girly drink. Soon after, our huge Korean seafood pancake ($9.95) came.  It's bland if you don't dip it in the soy-vinegar chili sauce. Also, it was a tad bit oily and wish it was more crunchier.

I ordered my usual Man du Gook ($8.95) which is a dumpling soup with green onions and egg. What a disappointment. The dumplings were already falling apart after moving it around in my bowl. 

The box dinner was a wise choice since heaping mounds of everything were devoured in minutes:  tender teriyaki beef, steamed white rice and simple iceberg lettuce salad. 

Arang definitely scores points because it has more choices and noticeably lower prices than the other 2 Korean restos in the area.  However, it loses points with me because there are no banchans served for late night eats!
author: Janice C.

description: This place is one of my favorite Korean restaurants in SF, cuz their food and service are both great!!! :) I guess it's gonna be the one serving almost all kinds of Korean food in SF. If you are looking for some Korean restaurants in here, you should check up this place at first :)
author: Yunho K.

description: Best Korean food i have found in San francisco. Their fried chicken is also good. The service is really good as well.
author: Serdamba B.

description:
I usually come here after work when I have a long day. My favorite thing to order here is the Soft Tofu Soup. I almost always get it, and it really never disappoints me. It's the perfect filler and great dinner to have with a beer, water, or tea. I also really enjoyed their chicken gizzard skewers. It sounds odd- I know. They are seriously one of the best side-dishes to have with beer. I really love the texture and saltiness with just a bit of onions and bell pepper. 

Will come back, like always!
author: Micah P.

description: The food is pretty good, but the hours are GREAT!! Serving food til 2am it's one of your few choices in the Fillmore District open late that doesn't ask if you want fries with that or if you would like your sub toasted. Hungry late and in the area? Here's your place.
author: Brian S.

description:
Surprise! I was taken here by two different people (who didn't know each other either by the way) who both claimed that this place would be one of my best Korean meals that opened this late.

Honestly, I can say I like Arang. They are flavorful, service is normally pretty friendly and they aren't a crazy wild drinking bar. It's just a place for you to get some food without being too overly pricey or dramatic.

They are pretty stingy with the banchans though so if you're a fan of the sweetened potatoes, take note!
author: Winè C.

description: Arang has authentic Korean comfort food at great prices and the lunch specials are a steal. These are a few of my favorite things: dol sot bibim bop with well done egg, kalbi tang, yuke jang, kim chee dol sot bibim bop with well done egg, dok boki, kalbi dinner box, and kim chi jigae. The service is always friendly and parking is ample in the Safeway parking lot. Need I say more?
author: Kevin C.

description:
Talk about mediocre korean food. I think you would get the same reaction you would get from a Chinese person when you ask them how they feel about Panda express. This just aint Korean food. I mean it is drinking Korean food, but they're shitty drinking Korean food. 
First off, service almost always sucks, except when the unni is working, but I"m afraid she quit. The right side of the restaurant is almost ALWAYS ignored. ugh.
2nd of all they give like 3 banchans, which seem kinda dirty and yucky and their miso soups are never scorching hot, always just lukewarm and salty. 

All the food is just whatevers, especially their ddukboki and omurice. It's not bad, but not great. And the portions are super danky. Don't get the budae chigae, unless you're tryna eat powdery kimchi soup with shin ramyun powder in it.

 Unfortunately, I come here VERY often, so I know wsup with all the food. They did improve, but they're still not the best in SF (although, sf doesn't have that many good korean joints). Do not compare SF korean restaurants with LA ktown ones, you will almost always be disappointed.
author: Joyce L.

description:
Wait staff didn't tell us that the SEAFOOD COMBO ONLY HAS  SQUID. Either fix the menu or inform the customers. 
The dinning room was very cold. The food on plates were cold. Only the soup was hot. Crunchy rice tea was the best part of the meal.
author: Lou F.

description:
So glad there was a restaurant open past 10:00 pm near the place my friends and I were staying. We were all so frikken hungry that it didn't really matter where or what we ate. Luckily, we saw a korean restaurant, so that was pretty awesome (I love korean food). 

It was nice and homey inside the restaurant and the workers were really accommodating to all 10 of us. We were served some sesame tea which wasn't too bad--- tastes like Rice Krispies tea. 

Good thing they weren't that busy so our orders came out pretty fast even though there were so many of us, but since we were all coupled up, most of our party kind of shared, but not I! Hahha. I ordered the (cold) bibimbap which was good. In my opinion, all (cold) bibimbaps taste the same no matter what restaurant I go to (could be different in Korea, who knows). I just added some hot sauce and I was good to go. I enjoyed my meal very much.

It wasn't the best korean restaurant I've been to and it wasn't the worst, so I would come back if I was in the area and if I was hungry late at night.
author: Jorgess M.

description: This is my most favorite Korean restaurant. Eat Hot Stoneware Bugogi will make you super satisfy in a cold day. I also like Short Rip. It doesn't salty like they usually make in other restaurants. You don't have to worry about the smell after getting out here. That's amazing. They just have the new sauces for the chicken. I have to try it soon.
author: Chi B.

description:
Thought I wrote a review for this place already, but guess I didn't. This place is pretty small and does get pretty packed. The place has a few tables and 3 booths. The place normally has 3 people working. The people waiting means this place is good. 

No one would be waiting around a place with homeless sleeping a few feet away if the food wasn't good.
author: M C.

description:
One of the best, at least top 3 korean eateries in SF! Service is mediocre but improved from a few years ago but food remains consistently delicious! I have been coming here for over 15 years!
They have lunch special deals that are well
Worth it! Dinner is pricey but average for korean food! They always play pop style music in different languages and sometimes in English. It is definitely a tastey place to go to late night! Well
Worth a try if just coming across this spot randomly as a tourist or maybe someone new to the neighborhood! Make your way!!!
author: Claire D.

description: Came here late one night with a friend. It was surprisingly kind of crowded. The beef tofu soup barely had any beef :( and also didn't come with the egg, which I've never seen before. And the bonchons were sad and few and served on a plastic dish.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
This is the place to go for good Korean food :) I love to eat here for the Bi bim baps, fish cakes, and of course the appetizers!!! Ironically what I love about Korean food is the appetizers. They give out a tray of regular kim chee, cucumber, fish cakes, etc.

I ate here today and I really loved the service, My friend and I came in waiting for one more person to come in, and the server let us sit there and take our time waiting and ordering. By the time our other friend came in we ordered and didn`t have to wait long. We took our time, ate, and was very satisfied, Today was one of the best days I`ve gone so far.

When I visited here before I remember how inattentive the servers actually were, some took a while to respond (probably depending on who it is, because the one who helped me today came by my table a lot) & sometimes the appetizers came late or not at all.. :|

Also to add on, the restaurant itself is tiny itself.. don`t come in huge groups over 4+ people. They have a bunch of tiny tables that can fit 2 people on one, 3 tables that can fit at least 4-5 people on it, and 3-4 bar seats.. that`s all.
author: Johanah I.

description: We Went there Monday night , had a wonderful seafood soup, and casserole soup, also the side dishes were amazing! Happy I found this place with authentic Korean food :)
author: Yev G.

description: I used to love this place till the most recent time I came here today. Ordered soft tofu soup vegetarian no onion. Soup came out with seafood and lots of onions in it so we have to send it back. Waitress brought back new soup with undercooked, bitter zucchini and still lots of onion.
