The place was pretty tiny but they seated the nine of us accordingly in a timely fashion. The service wasn't bad at all, they took our orders & we got our food pretty quickly. The waitress checked up on us every now & then & refilled our waters. 

One of the best parts of Korean cuisine that I love are the complimentary appetizers. I was snacking on them so much that I barely ate my actual food. I got a bento box which consisted of pot-stickers, a salad, pickled veggies, rice, & Korean spare ribs. It was good but nothing to rave about. It filled me up but I can't see myself craving this. 

The thing that made this experience less favorable was the fact that two of the three cars that we parked in the parking lot near the restaurant got towed. Its apparently Safeway's parking lot but this plaza consisted of other restaurants & stores that you'd think would share the lot. So be careful where you park!
author: Kris B.

description:
The good thing about this place is the price.  It's hard to find cheap Korean food in the city without a price tag, especially for dinner.

However, I was underwhelmed by the quality of food.  I got the BBQ beef box (8.95), and the beef had a bunch of fat on the edges.  My friends were also not huge fans of their dishes (the bi bim bop and the kimchee fried rice).

Also, the service sucked.  We were there for late night (around 9:30), and there was only one waitress for the restaurant (which was small, but surprisingly busy for that time of night).
author: Alison L.

description:
Been a customer for 10 years.

Parking is usually not a problem. Prices are awesome, especially at lunch time. The service is good, and the business hours are great!
author: Ana A.

description:
Oh how I miss the old Arang =(

Yea they like changed ownership, dont remember when but I know they did. One day I returned after not eating here for like a couple of months...and UGH I was disgusted.

I always order the usual, a pick of a bento + a pick of either the seafood or beef bibimbap + soju ofcourse!

Ordered me a Spicy Pork Bento + Seafood Bi Bim Bap + Peach Soju.  How can you go wrong?

Ugh yea... it can go wrong when:
 
Booboo #1. The spicy pork was freaking BACON cooked in a watery spicy sauce! I normally LOVE bacon, but this was not no crispy bacon, so trust me I know my cut of pork!  Each piece of pork I picked up was HALF FAT.

Booboo #2. Yea I know I ordered the Seafood BiBimBap..but wussup with the FISHY stank smell?!?   I put EXTRA of that spicy sauce to try to "fix" this, and yet NOTHING could have saved that.  

Booboo #3. Me and Soju has always had a love hate relationship, its always love love love you, until the next morning when I find myself passed out in front of my door, missing one shoe, and with a pounding headache. The problem here is that....my freaking Peach SOJU had practically NO SOJU in it! It tasted good (overly sweet), but now I know its cus they didnt add enough Soju!

Booboo #4. I walked out unsatisfied, and SOBER! Had so much leftovers, but didn't want to take it to go, cus it was just plain BOOBOO. And we knew we was just going to throw it away.  

Old Arang, you will always have a place in my heart! But the current Arang needs step it up!
author: Deanna T.

description:
We love coming to this restaurant. We discovered it from a Korean friend. The place is small though! We've taken our two small kids there and some of their seating is "cozy" Thankfully no one has minded having them around even when they're drinking. They usually play with them. (I guess I've just got cute kids lol) 

Anyway moving on, the service has always been good except for one time. They put a hot pot right in front of my youngest; and of course she touched it and burnt her finger!! I didn't realize how bad it was b/c I didn't see it happen, just her crying. Otherwise I would have been sure to say something. 

The food is really good. I'm sorry I don't remember the exact names. But we always get the bulgogi, kimchi with tofu, and the seafood soup. (Its has a bright red color, it almost looks like sauce with mussels, clams, some meat and tofu) We always get a new dish we haven't tried with each visit. Last week we got squid on skewers. But for $5 we got like 4 small pieces of squid with vegetables. What a waste of money!
author: Marjorie N.

description:
I used to hate cutting my meat when I was a kid, especially whenever I was eating kalbi because I would first have to cut the meat away from the ribs then cut it into manageable portions. That's probably one major reason why I like this place, they already cut the meat off of the bone for you and into good-sized portions. That's two less steps between me and putting yummy short ribs into my tummy. 

I've been here countless times now and this is one of my top spots to grab some inexpensive and satisfying Korean food. I always order the kalbi bento box whenever I come here now. I've tried a few of the other items on the menu the first few times that I ate here, but I've found my favorite so I'm sticking to it.
author: Erich D.

description:
Ended up here after checkin' out the closing night flick at the SFIAFF at the Sundance Kabuki. We was hongry after the festivities so we beelined it to Arang. It's open late, the food is good. Why not?

The place isn't that big so if you're coming through with 8-10 of your partners, expect to wait. If it's just about 2-4, you're good. We got seated in about 5-7 minutes. I ordered a "hamburger" type plate which looked like a loko moko coz it had an egg too. I was curious so I tried it. Not too bad. It tasted like a Korean loko-moko. Bingo!

Cool late night joint if you're in that area of the Fillmore for some grub after-hours.

I'm gonna back and try the bi bim bap.
author: Ivan F.

description:
Very yummy. Best Korean food in town. Descent price. Kimchi soup is the best. 
Bi Bim Bap is a must try!
author: Heather B.

description:
I would not come here for authentic Korean food.

HOWEVER, this is the one and ONLY place I go to for the oh so delicious rahbokki dish (spicy ricecakes with ramen) and the boodaejjigae.  We also usually get soondae and dip it in the rahbokki sauce.  Basically this is a good place to come for boonshik (informal Korean foods).
author: Jane K.

description:
This place does get my vote as one of the good K-food places in the City. I think the place is reasonably priced. (40 dollars for 2 persons) 

The menu has a great variety  which are tasty and the banchan spread is both good and generous.  Service is friendly too.
A friend brought me here for kalbitang and I've quickly adopted it as my personal favorite dish.  The portion (and meat!) is generous and the soup is yummy!

Come for good K-food but be prepared to leave with a full stomach slight lighter wallet
author: James M.

description:
I come here pretty often and what keeps me coming back is the food to price ratio. It's basic Korean food, nothing too special about it but it still satisfies my Korean food cravings and a decent price. The service is pretty good and the food comes out relatively quick. 

For a quick korean food fix, Arang is the place to go!
author: Esther K.

description:
Decent Korean food that's open late night.





... One time , they ran out of jap chae. How did they run out of jap chae!? *sobs*
author: Susy C.

description:
bi bim bap isn't hard to mess up...but I have to say I have tasted better. It just wasn't very good. The rice was too mushy and the veggie weren't good.

I gave it a 1 star because of the service. My friends and me wanted change for our bill, but our waiter assumed ALL the change was for tip. uh...yeah right? you barely talked to us and we had to wave you down to get our bill.
author: Dorris W.

description:
It's quite possible that nostalgia influences my rating for Arang but I consider this place my comfort food.  Around 8 years ago I used to come here during my grad school days and I either ended up drunk or came here drunk.  

Fast forward to the present and the circumstances are the same and I still really like this place, mainly because of value and speed of service. 

The food won't knock your socks off but it will keep your belly warm and your wallet full.
author: Roger H.

description:
Cannot get enough of this place...I can eat this everyday & everynight!!

I always get the Arang Combo w/ beef or chicken.

comes with...

* Potstickers (Gyoza)
* Vermicelli Noodles
* Shredded Potatoes
* Tempura
* Rice & Salad
Cost: $10

Arang Restaurant [click below - pictures]
http://www.xanga.com/icantsee?nextdate=8%2f12%2f2008+2%3a7%3a36.603&direction=n
author: Kenny C.

description: I have been eatiing here for 5 years I never write a review for this resturant , I the early year which is last 5 years I wold say this resturant is excellence,  good service and good food but in the pass 2 years the servers have changed and the service are bad make me just want to take it only togo.
author: Nattapol N.

description:
One of my favorite spots to go to for late nite eats and drinking.  Been meaning to write a review for this place for the longest time and again I dnt like sharing places I really like cuz its hard enough tryin to get a seat at this place at certain times.

I was introduced to this place years back in my clubbing days from one my good guy friends.  We used to roll up in this place 15 deep if not more after the club or goin out and we would take up that whole corner section by the mirrors..lol...those days!

Its always a good time goin to this place.  Except maybe one time on a first date and the alcohol couldnt help me that night to get thru it...lol.  But every time i bring in a new person they love it and they go there w/o tellin me..u A$$es!!  This place can be fun especial the people who eat there Ive meet some of the coolest folks around. Some are even cool enough to let u try some of their dishes they are eating if u ask nice enough what they are eating.

But the food is good no matter what u order. Especially the pot stickers...hahaha we always have to order our own cuz no one wants to share...lol! The fried glass noodles are also very good.

The place is open pretty late. I think they close like 2 but they never seem to kick anyone out even thou its passed that. The music inside is pretty interesting.  Techno asian ...lol...not sure what u call it but for sure I feel like speed racing after being there. The parking is in the safeway shopping area complex. Its gotten strict they only allow 2 hour parking in the lot and they start towing and for reals there are tow trucks in the lot waiting.  I guess people be partying a lil too much there and leaving theirs cars...lol...i dnt...

Two solid key items to order the Pot stickers and the Peach Soju = a good nite. Plus I love their potato salad and the brown rice tea that comes with toasted popcorn on top..lol its the lil things!!!
author: Christine M.

description:
I love love love love love love Arang! Good and RELIABLE bento boxes, udon and soups, and cheap little robata grilled skewers, which really hit the spot at when you want a hot, spicy and SUBSTANTIAL midnight snack. I don't know what I would do without this place!

Bento boxes are very well rounded with soup, salad, vermicelli noodles, potato spears, rice and the meat of your choice. Sometimes the waitress will throw in some edamame to snack on beforehand too. One time we got the sweet candy chex mix! Hahaha. I can never entirely finish the box no matter how hungry I am, so I usually end up with leftovers for lunch the next day.

Udon and other entrees besides the bento boxes come will a neat little kimchee/bean curd platter.

MMMM hite beer.

And you all KNOW you LOVE the bumpin' K-POP trance/pop music.
author: Chelsea P.

description: I came here on a chilly late evening and there was no wait. I got the spicy tofu soup and it was really good! my favorite is always the unlimited  complimentary bon chon dishes! My boyfriend got the bim bam bop which I thought was really good! I would recommend this place to anyone who's passing by the city for some good korean food. The service was just ok to me; nobody really came to check up on us, I had to flag them down when i needed anything. Besides that, other people sitting around us had food coming out that looked really delicious as well! I am looking forward to trying more things on their menu!
author: Lien T.

description:
I am between 3 and four stars here, it depends on the visit and what you get.  The Chicken Udon was average, the Bi Bim Bap was very good.  The Salmon Teriyaki was average, the Kim Chee Fried Rice was excellent.  Sensing a pattern?  I say stick to the Korean fare.

The restaurant was small but is easy to order to go.  The staff was friendly and has always had people in their eating when I have gone.  Prices are reasonable, the menu is large and they have karaoke at night if that adds anything for you (or takes something away)
author: Jay B.

description:
I wouldn't have ventured into this restaurant if it weren't for a friend who lives in the 'hood.  It's completely unassuming especially next to the "fashion" boutique next door with spandex tube dresses hanging in the window.

I digress...

This restaurant is good place to venture if you're looking for a quick fix for a Korean craving.  When we walked in around 7 pm, it was relatively empty but within minutes, plenty of other people streamed in and filled up the tables around us.  

I wasn't starved, so I ordered the spicy tofu soup. It was boiling hot and filled to the brim with tons of silken tofu.  I was a little surprised by the cooked egg smack dab in the middle.  A few pieces of clam floated around and I think there were some straggling strips of beef as well. I enjoyed the flavor...could have been a tad bit spicier. I asked for medium, next time, I'll ask them to step it up a bit. 

My friend ordered up the BBQ beef combo plate, which was a great value for the moola.  The BBQ was well seasoned, a little sweet and salty all at the same time.  It came with shreds of potatoes, mung bean noodles, a side salad, and rice. 

All in all, we skated away with a bill that was just over a 20 spot.  Not shabby...and we had leftovers to boot!
author: Evelyn K.

description: By far my favorite korean restaurant in San Francisco. Their spicy fried chicken is the best, and their seafood bibimbap. They're always playing some catchy kpop music and the wait is usually never too long. good place for dinner
author: Linh P.

description:
I love arang for lunch and for late night eats.  There are not alot of options in SF for Korean food unless you marry a fob/date a fob or your room mate is.   Right now I'm SOL so I find myself here for lunch, late night anju and for some holiday tunes.   Also I tell myself its healthier than Popeyes and more filling than Jubilee.  
PS I don't come here without a friend b/c the Safeway parking lot can be a little shady.
author: Sarah C.

description:
One of the best Bi Bim Bap I have eaten in the bay area! Their other food is really good too but I usually always get bi bim bap just because it is the item to get!

Their tea is really good but I always have a hard time getting refills :( They really need to work on their service.
author: Jaime L.

description:
Open late. I'm still a novice with good Korean eats, but they had good bibimbap and dukbokki. Have some Hite and their lemon soju to wash it all down...

Got there at 1130pm and parking was super easy - there's a practically empty Safeway lot right next door...
author: Jenn C.

description:
Four of us had dinner here and we ordered 3 dishes.  So much food, we couldn't finish it all.  There was this casserole dish that was just nuts.  The soup was so red and there were mushrooms, meat, and rice cakes in it, PLUS we added ramen.  Our eyes were definitely bigger than our stomaches that night.  Food was ok and I wouldn't mind eating here again.  

I really like that we didn't have to drive around the streets of SF for 15+ minutes to find parking, you can just park in the same lot Safeway is in!
author: Sally Q.

description:
We decided to eat here because it was 10ish and this place was still open. We decided to split everything: short ribs, the spam casserole dish, and a tofu soup. 

The ribs were a little touch and the spam in the casserole didn't taste like spam at all. The food was okay but I don't think the quality is worth the price. 

PS - They had a really interesting playlist going on in the background. (Korean to Feist to some oldies).  hehe.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Took a little time to find this restaurant. You can't see it from the street. It's around the corner from a Subway Hut a little ways along some open space. Very small storefront where the door is.  I'm a fan of everything Korean (I'm Chinese). Discovered a Korean dessert called Patbingsu which is really good. I think Arang is the only restaurant in SF that has it (at least mentioned on Yelp). Found 2 places in Santa Clara and 1 in San Mateo. I started off with dinner. I had the Soft Tofu Soup. It was only $9.95 and was decent size. Not the smallest or biggest I've ever had. This place has Japanese and Korean food and lunch specials. Have to try the Fried Chicken tossed with Spicy Korean BBQ sauce (I've made it myself before. It's less messy to have someone else make it). I'm going to have to try other dishes. Prices are reasonable. Saw another table that had this relatively large metal bowl over a portable stove that had noodles, spam, sausage, vegetables in a spicy broth. Have to try that next time. Ordered my Patbingsu. Took only about 5 minutes for them to bring it out. It was sized for one. Had ice shavings, red beans, corn chex flakes, fruit cocktail, a little ice cream and thinly sliced banana. I finished the whole thing. Only $5.95. I forgot to take a pic of my food. Next time. Service was decent. No issues. I'll write another review after I've tried a few more dishes.

Atmosphere in the place was nice. Only had about 8 tables in the place. So probably not good for groups. Not sure if there is a back room or upstairs. Music system played a mixture of English and Korean music. Not too loud.
author: Ronald C.

description: I felt like it was a go to place for many people of the neighborhood. It's a small place and it looks like it gets packed quickly. The food was standard except the soft tofu soup packed quite the punch. It was really good. If you get the chicken plate, get the spicy one. The plain one lacked flavor but at least it was tender. It's affordable and you will be full.
author: Eve C.

description: Good quality Korean food in combination with quick service is a good strategic way to drive for my returning business. Although it is located in a sketchy part of the fillmore, the good food and easy parking will get me to come back. Their open late, so if you have that urge for some korean food at 12am, Arang's got you covered !
author: Jeff C.

description:
Arang is my go to Korean restaurant. The place is small yet the food is packed with huge flavors. I always leave this place so full and can't believe how much I ate. The portions are generous to say the least. 

The service is prompt and friendly. The only drawback is the mini-mall it's located in. There are a few panhandlers and homeless folks who can be a bit aggressive and loud.
author: Alan L.

description:
Came here the other night with a group of friends, not a place recommended for those of you that have a large group. Prices are decent for the food, the soju is a different story. But starting off with the food, my friend and I split the Kimchi Fried rice, and the Spicy Tofu Soup. The tofu soup was delicious, so was the kimchi fried rice but I wasn't a fan of the corn bits in the rice. You get of course as with any other korean mean, ban chan. I usually love the ban chan korean restaurants have to offer but this place was alright. The jap chae I tried from my friends dinner box was disappointing. It was mushy and didn't taste like how jap chae should taste. But I would say for the price, they offer pretty big portions. 

As for their soju, I think it was $9-$10 for a bottle of plain soju which is I guess normal with most places. HOWEVER! I would not order the flavored soju again. They sell it by the "pitcher," which in my mind, I was thinking of your average water pitcher. No, it's not, it's about half. Which I wouldn't have minded so much if it didn't cost $25? It was either $25, or $25+ And also, they don't have the price written up for how much it costs, maybe the menu did, I don't quite remember. But $25?!?!?! Really!?!? I can get 2 bottles of it somewhere else. 

All in all, if you're coming for food, this place is pretty good. If you came to drink, I'd say go somewhere else. So 3.5 stars for me. =]
author: Annie W.

description: Compared to all the other places I've been for Korean food and soju, Arang is probably the cheapest, and best tasting place. It's a lot smaller than like the spot and playground, and more of a chill, sit down dinner place, but I really liked it here.  We ordered the kimchi fried rice, kimchi tofu stew, BBQ beef bento box, and the redbean and mixed fruit icee dessert. Everything was good and came in pretty big portions. Our waitress was very nice and quick with giving us more fish cakes and kimchi. The pitcher of yogurt soju was big and even though you can taste how strong it is, it was still very good. It's very easy to find parking around the restaurant and its open late. I would definitely come back if I'm craving Korean food again
author: Katherine C.

description:
I love Korean food, so I was excited when my Korean GF suggested this place I haven't been before. 
The place is very cafe like..so no issues with seating. The waitresses here are very sweet and attentive.
Unfortunately, the food is mediocre and some of the items on the menu are a bit puzzling--The American Camp Soup--spicy korean soup with instant raman, sliced hotdogs and SPAM?!?! Way over the top!! It's like having KFC, Taco Bell Nachos, and a Big Mac all on one plate. The place also feels a bit dirty...Okay..not just feel..but really just is...I prefer to pick up some side dishes from Woo Ri Market and call it a day
author: Mimi T.

description: All around, pretty good. Been here a few times now and tried a bunch of stuff. All quite tasty, with the seafood bibimbap standing out, and the fried chicken wings not quite so. But it's open late, the parking is convenient with the big Safeway lot behind, and it's certainly popular. Despite my only 3* have already been there a number of times, and each time quite satisfied.
author: Bruce C.

description:
This is one of my favorite Korean Restaurants in the city. I never came across any dish, that I did not like or love. 
Here are my favorite dishes: Kabli, spicy pork, beef udon, gyoza, the clear noodles (i forgot how to spell it in Korean), rice stick noodles, spicy tofu soup and much more. Also, if you love flavored Soju...this is the place. 
Prices seem good, there's plenty of parking and they are open late. What could you possible ask for...after a long night...hot soup! The best, especially after a night of drinking. 
Though, i do have to remind you...not to wear anything nice, because you come out smelling like Korean food. ;) It's also a small place, but they have accommodated us before with a party of 10.
author: Lai S.

description:
Came here for dinner.  And, it was just okay. Nothing too memorable, but nothing was awful.    

Fried chicken -crispy fried goodness. Super bland.  But, they give you a salt rub with a mayo sauce that you can dip into making it extra flavorful.  
Kimchi stew (for 2) -HUGE pot of food that can easily be shared for 3!  
Seafood Pancake -pretty good, but I've had better.  I wish the pancake was more crispy.  
Peach Soju -so delicious!  

Word of advice!  Don't park in the lot next to the restaurant if you're planning on staying longer than 2 hours!  It's run by safeway and golden gate towing company comes and tow you!  It was pretty big damper on the night.
author: stephanie c.

description:
I really think this place truly deserves 5 stars. I know before, I rated it 4 stars, but that was 2 years ago, and I've been here a considerable amount of times now to really speak about it. And to top it off, I have a coworker who comes here RELIGIOUSLY - like, I'd say at LEAST once a week, and this is one of her favorite Korean places to eat at in the city.

I came here recently on a lunch break because I was craving something simple. I didn't feel like sitting and eating at a table, so I ordered food to go. I asked for the kimchi fried rice, but EXTRA spicy. And you know what? They did just that!

I'm a simple person (sometimes, HA), and there are days when I have simple requests. I'm just glad that I was able to satisfy my craving for the day. :)
author: Melissa D.

description: Great place for take-out orders as they get it done in 10 mins every time, plus decent prices and good lunch specials. I've tried it twice, the food was good. I will definitely come again.
author: Daria S.

description:
One of the few cheap Korean eats in the area. It's a tiny hole in the wall place, but serves up pretty good and authentic Korean food. It reminds me of a hole in the wall drinking places like "indoor pojang macha" or "sojubang" in Korea. 

If you like spicy food and spam, you MUST try their Boo Dae Jjee Gae (translation: "Army Stew"). Spicy stew full of spam, hot dogs, ramen noodles, rice cakes, and veggies! It's big enough for 2 - 3 people, maybe even 4 if you order other things.

The menu is full of delicious "anju" -- the dishes that you typically eat when you drink. Think of it as Korean Tapas or Izakaya fare? And of course, they have beer and Soju (Korean version of vodka like alcohol) and mixed Soju (Soju cocktail that tastes like lemonade, among others)

It's a fun place to get in and out for a quick lunch or get totally drunk (just don't drink and drive)

As with all other Korean places, banchan (side dishes) are free and free flowing. :D
author: Su K.

description:
I never really liked this place b4 because i didnt know what to order except for the tourist stuff. But now to my new found knowledge I would recomend this.

1.The spam sausage in stew good to eat with 2 or more

2. the spicy pork bone soup good to eat with 2 or more peeps

3. Used to get the beef bi bim bap but now i moved on to the kim chee bi bim bap.

4.I recommend the dessert they only have one there.

There kalbi is good and really reasonably priced.

Didnt really like the chicken gizzard skewers, and there seafood stuff.

Oh yea and MOST MOST MOST importantly if you want a good buzz, Do Not drink the regular soju or fruity ones.

You have to get the chum chu rum Hyori edition. (Dang she fine)  It taste like goose and goes down easier and doesnt make u tired....

Service is good and quick.
author: DOM d.

description:
I'm not a really picky eater and I'm a huge fan of Korean food.
Their pricing is reasonable for the quality of the food.
Don't know if this happens to everyone else, but I always seem to have a hard time calling the server over.
It's a good place to stop by for a quick meal.
Love their bibimbap and their tofu soups. 
The sides are mehhhh.

Overall, it's a decent place.
author: Victoria D.

description: I'm a big fan of Arang. Love their kimchi fried rice and the dessert. This place is really small so just order to go!
author: Xiaosi Y.

description:
Showed up with my wife looking for good Korean food.  We walk in, all Koreans eating there.  Great sign.  

This place is great.  Food was wonderful (we had a soup an bi bim bop), staff friendly.  A definite return.
author: michael d.

description:
This place serves up cheap, delicious korean food!  I came here for lunch w/ a few coworkers and really enjoyed my meal!  I only wish it was within walking distance of the office.

For $8.00, including tax and tip, I had the soft tofu soup with pieces of beef and clam.  The food came out pretty quickly and we were served 5-6 different types of banchan (which they happily refilled for us).  It would have been nice if the tofu soup was just a bit more spicy.  Still, I'm not complaining because it was yummy and hit the spot for me! 

I can't wait to come back to try their other lunch items.  All the other food that my coworkers ordered looked delicious!
author: Cynthia H.

description: This place is awesome. Good is great and affordable. Place is a little small but wait is usually not too bad. taste much better than won mi but it does close at two. Wish they open much later!!!!
author: Becca L.

description:
This little Korean place in the Fillmore is decent for its prices and portions. We shared the Meat variety soup base which was excellent with lots of veggie, spam, sausage, noodles and Shanghainese style flat noodles. We also tried the short ribs and kal-bi tang. They were both tasty and decently priced and we were stuffed.

Service was sketchy but guess she was the only server around the entire time. Interestingly, there was also loud Korean music blaring in the background but overall, a great experience and casual place to enjoy the soup in the cold evenings.
author: Yan M.

description:
Definitely appreciate the no fuss Korean food.  It is not Chinese - American - fusion anything.  It is just straight up Korean food.  

Everything I've ordered has been good.  They have an expansive menu, everything from Kal Bi, Fried Chicken, Soups, Vegetarian dishes, etc...

I LOVE my spicy dishes and Arang definitely spices it up:)
author: HY L.

description:
I came here on the random one night and was quite impressed. My bf and I were hungry tigers so we each ordered one bento box and an appetizer of calamari.

As I recall, the price was decent, the food was yumm and the service was just okay.  They weren't that busy but everything took a long time....from ordering to getting the check, it was pretty slow.  

I would come back here again if I'm in the mood for korean food but don't want to shell out an arm and a leg.  I noticed that people were drinking here so I figured...ohh it's probably one of those korean bars/restaurants like places and I thought it was pretty good for what it was.

It's open late which is good and if you're in the mood for decently price and a decent sized portion of korean food, I'd recommend it.  4 stars for what it is. If you're expecting fancy shmancy or something gourmet then don't come here.
author: Zu W.

description:
Decent Prices and always open late! 

I love their Barley Tea,.

Will definitely come back!
author: Emily L.

description: My first time in a Korean restaurant. They had some fun music playing and the food was pretty good. The service was quick and efficient too. I'd go back for sure. Thanks!
author: Beth S.

description:
You've heard me say it before, I'm not a huge fan of Korean restaurants in San Francisco.  Typically, they are way overpriced and under-flavored, leaving me with an empty wallet and a dissatisfied belly.  I recently went to Korea and found the bar raised even higher after sampling the classics, mastered to perfection, and imaginative new creations that left me wanting more.

This said, I was really not at all looking forward to trying out another San Francisco Korean restaurant recently with some friends, but I went anyway because I still hadn't eaten my fill of Korean after my recent trip and was willing to lower my standards just to get my fix.  

Arang was surprisingly satisfying.  The prices are less than other San Francisco restaurants, and the taste was actually decent.  They didn't skimp on ingredients because of their lower price (in fact, their hae mul pa jun (seafood pancake) was packed with seafood), and they were generous with the side dishes.

One downside was the wait to get a seat.  Apparently, there are plenty of people who figured out that Arang is a decent joint.  Too bad it's super tiny.  Plan to wait for a table.  Check it out, though.
author: Jenny K.

description:
The lunch box specials were cheap.. teriyaki chicken, rice, soup, salad, noodles, and wonton for under $7!  This place does not offer any appetizers!!  We ordered a plate of tempura and it was freaking $12!  I ordered the spicy chicken sizzling plate.. it wasn't that spicy, just very oily.  The soup that was brought out wasn't hot.. so that was a tad disappointing.

Parking is semi-easy since it's right by the Safeway parking lot.  Service was quick but towards the end they tend to cater to the diners that just walked in rather than checking in on us.

If you want the lunch special, it is worth it but if you go for any other meals then it's expensive.. freaken $13 for my sizzling chicken plate.. not worth it.
author: Tram N.

description:
"Yo Crazy Dave, remember that soup we had last time you visited me in LA?" -DM

"Yeah, yeah that's kal bi tang." -CD

"All I remember was being so f*ck*d up but that soup was so good.  I want some more of that shit." -DM

"Oh I know a place close to where me and Fos use to live, near the ghetto." -CD

Sorry, I didn't mean to let the horse out of the barn, but that's how I got here.  Kal bi tang, a clean and refreshing short rib soup and it was de-licious.  Second time around I learned "Danger" was not my middle name.  I tried some kim chee, spam, kung fu, sausage casserole and it's been changed to "Monsta" since.







All names, location, and date, may have been changed to protect the identity of those involved.
author: Donsta L.

description:
Had my first satisfying meal here a few nights ago with one of my closest girlfriends.  We shared the Meat variety soup which was YUM with lots of veggies, sliced spam & sausage and ramen noodles.  There was so much in a serving for two that I had enough leftovers to count as one full meal the next day.

And upon seeing how red the pot came, I thought it was going to be ultra spicy, but it wasn't....it was just right.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Korean comfort food served up in this smallish spot in the Western addition.

I finally discovered a spot in the Bay that makes ddukbokki with chol myun!  Spicy sauteed rice cakes that's usually served alone, but here they add chol myun, a chewy noodle that's perfect for slurping up the tasty sauce. That dish gets 5 stars in my book.  

We also tried:
chicken gizzards ok, a bit too chewy
fried chicken - tasted like chinese fried chicken, not bad
spam and sausage casserole wiith ramen noodles and kimchi - guilty pleasure
kimchi fried rice - good 
seafood pajun - pretty spicy with lots of seafood 
yogurt soju - pretty sweet

No panchan here for some reason, and you might be in for a long wait since the space is so small. People tend to linger too, since it's a drinking place.
author: Derrick V.

description: I love this place!  The menu is huge...but I can't really get myself to try something new since I pretty much only ever stick to their dol sot bim bim bap or soft tofu soup.  Their bulgogi bento box is delicious too. Come early though as this place tends to get crowded.
author: Audrey P.

description:
Getting better! A lot better!

Came in here this week and decided to check out how the place is doing and surprisingly THE FOOD WAS GREAT! Looks like they change up the staff a little bit and we can taste the DIFFERENCE. The usual late night korean joint is BACK! The korean pancakes were cooked perfectly, the fish egg tofu soup was delicious and the korean sausage was PERFECTO! .... Oh, how i miss this place so much, now its back. Ill be coming in way more often now. Maybe next time i update arang, itll be a five star! *crossing fingers*
author: Frankie L.

description:
Shmeh. 

My GF and I ordered to go, and I therefore am keeping this at 3 stars.  I want to be careful here, since as we all know the star system is very complex.  I like to review on a relative basis.  I'm going with 3 stars, because relative to OTHER korean BBQ places, that's what it deserves.  Compared to the typical "asian take-out food" whether that be chinese vietnemese thai etc, I woudl have given them a 4.

Korean BBQ places (in my humble opinion) should be judged on 3 things.

1) tea
2)Kimchee
3) Spare Ribs (this is the important one.

Bi bim bab is important too, (and the spicy tofu soup don't get me started) but since I went tog0 I didn't want to end up dissapointed.  

1)  tea was bomb.  I liked it.  They had the cracked rice or whatever in there that pleased me immensley.

2) Kimchee was acceptable.  i won't say out of this world, but it was nice and the spice level was good, not great.

3) You know you'll be dissapointed with spare ribs when they aren't attached to bones.  I'm sorry, but maybe I'm just an old soul... but they just taste better when they're cooked on teh bone!!  They were still tasty and sweet.... just missing that boneful -oompha you'd hope from a BBQ Korean tasty beef meal!

The assortment of sides we had were good too.  Gyoza was tasty, and teh virmacelli (no  I can't spell..) was really really good.  Maybe it was cause we went to go, but the tempura was sub-par and chewy rather than crispy.

Good enough for me to reccomend as a togo meal anytime; particularly near that filmore area.  I'll be back to sit down and see if quality gets better or not.
author: Joseph F.

description:
My fiance turned me onto this place years and years ago.  Another hole in the wall type of place that is really good for some korean food.  I love their Jap Chae, potstickers, beef udon, and kim chee cucumbers here.  This place is good for late night eating or just a night out on the town with some of your girls to have some soju.  

I always ask for extra cucumbers when I go because I alone can eat those like no tomorrow.  

This place is open really late, so if you are looking for good eats...try this place out.  Their bathroom is a little sketchy is so is their parking lot because it looks kinda ghetto, but other than that...the food is delish.
author: Mary T.

description:
This place is a great little secret in the Webster plaza. Its easy to miss on the outside and inside the restaurant is kind of a hole in the wall. 

I work on Laguna and anytime I'm craving Kim Chee Fried Rice, this is my go-to place. I first heard about it from a coworker and I love the fact that they put spam and corn in the kim chee friend rice. It's also cheap! for the lunch special, i believe its only $6.50, maybe a little more. they have other lunch specials that are also cheap. The bento lunch boxes come with rice, soup, salad, yam noodles, choice of entree, and pot sticker. Its a lot of food for $6.50-$7. It's not my top choice Korean restaurant, but I would definitely come back whenever I work and would like a cheap lunch.
author: Connie C.

description: Came here for one reason only. kimchi bokkeumbap. it was delicious! They even have patbingsu here! I've only tried that in korea never in the US. It was pretty good. nothing like the ones in Seoul though. Still worth a try to see what's it like.
author: Terry S.

description:
I usually come here when I'm feeling sick and each time I'm done eating their food, I feel a lot better. I love their tea. I usually get the soft tofu soup/combination lunch. This place is good for small parties since it's a small place. Even at 2pm for a late lunch, the place is decently busy. So I make sure I order right away or I will have to wait another 5-10 minutes for the waitress to come to take my order.

Today one of the waitresses accidentally dropped a stone plate and the bowl broke but didn't hit me at all. It landed right next to my foot and the waitress was really apologetic. I was more worried for the waitress than my foot because she seem really scared and I kept telling her that it was okay and don't worry about it as I continued to eat and enjoy my bowl of udon. The manager came and helped cleaned up. They moved me to another seat and I kept on eating. The manager came up and asked if my shoes were okay. He apologized and told me that they were not going to charge me for that meal. :) Now that is good customer service.
author: G F.

description:
This is the only Korean restaurant I eat in the city and it's so good!

Prices are decent and won't make me go broke. I like how this restaurant opens pretty late so I come here often after a session of karaoke a block away. Food is great here! Bi bim bap is one of my favorite dishes here. The red bean paste that comes along with it is sooo good too. I also like the bbq pork box and the seafood pancake. Mmm... AND I love their tea! It has like popcorn or rice grains in it...

I'm only deducting one star because the service is not that great. They don't check up on you often so you might have to ask for more tea and for your bill. And sometimes they forget if you asked for more water or whatever.
author: Vivian L.

description: This place is located right nearby the Fillmore center and opens late! This -place is perfect for a casual date or just hanging out with friends! I ordered Kim Chi Stew with Tofu, Bulgogi, and DonPuki. Their dish are so vibrant and flavorful. I would definitely go back to this place. Try their donpuki!
author: Alvin J.

description:
Dear Arang,

Thank you for always satisfying my craving for Korean bar food.  I especially love the kimchee jigae and the shrimp omelette rice (oh-mu-rice).   Nothing beats good ole ketchup on fried rice.  Your ban-chans are mighty tasty too, though the egg dish looks spoiled, it tastes perfect.  I appreciate the Korean power ballads and occasional Korean pop music that blasts throughout your restaurant.  Somehow I feel the pain of the Korean singer while I slurp my soup. 

I promise to visit at least every other month.  I know I don't live in the city anymore, but you are always on my mind anytime I think of "duk buk ki."  

Please continue to offer good Korean food for a relatively cheap price.  

I miss you dearly.  

Best wishes,
Your biggest cheerleader
author: Soo Jin K.

description: Been here a couple times and everything has been good.  I love the tea that they give you. The spicy pork and bibimbap are very tasty and well portioned.  I can't wait to try their other dishes!
author: Christy A.

description:
This is actually my favorite local go-to restaurant for late night eating. Open until 2am, plenty of parking in the Safeway lot, small homey feel, and most important good, relatively cheap food.

Been here on several occasions now but tonight solidified the 4 stars. It's been CONSISTENTLY good. They serve no frills Korean food, tofu soups, bi bim bap, chap chae, fried rice omelet, yu ge jang, etc. They also have the grilled meats but they cook it in the kitchen and not at your table.

Tonight I had the Soon Du Bul ($8.95) and it was hot, spicy, full of flavor, and contained fresh hunks of tofu. VERY satisfying on a cold SF evening. My cousin had the Yu Ge Jang ($9.95) and that was super yummy too. Spicy beef soup, more pure beef taste, more broth, no tofu. Really good.

I've had the casserole for 2, dok bok gi, and a variety of other dishes. I have always been happily satisfied. The only downsides are the unexciting pan chan or small side dishes. It's usually a cabbage, a cucumber, potato salad, bean curd, and egg served in one of those multi-divisional plates (like the ones used for little kids). Service can be splotchy too.

But I can overlook all that in favor of the good food, under $10 entrees, and barley tea. Oh and of course, the crowning melon gum at the end of the meal. Who can resist that?
author: Cindy W.

description:
In sum, I don't want to patronize a place where the managers are patronizing to their employees.

Worse part of my experience at this place was hearing the Korean server/owner/manager(?) yell at her Latino employee.  Her "critique" was bordering on abuse.  I hope he has legal status and can can quit and move to a restaurant where the managers/owners appreciate the hard work he does for them.

As for the food, it was just OK.  I haven't eating a lot of Korean food, so I'm not going to delve into how amazing it is or isn't or compare to other Korean spots.  It was spicy with all that red stuff which they put on a lot of the dishes.  I had the seafood stoneware dish.  It was more fun for the experience than the flavor. The best part about the meal was the side dishes, including the potato salad like one and fried veggie cakes.
author: Cara J.

description: SF doesn't have great Korean food so instead of going to a half ass over priced place, I'd rather come to Arang for some cheap fast Korean delights.  Food is consistently good and service for a Korean restaurant is pretty decent.
author: Suz L.

description: Bento boxes are a great deal; less than 10bucks for dinner. Their BBQ Beef is always flavorful and filling. They give out melon gum after every meal for fresh breath.
author: Alisa M.

description:
I came here with two of my friends and was hoping for some good Korean food. I was not super satisfy after leaving the restaurant.
 The food was blend and the only thing i thought i order was good was the gyoza in my Korean bento box. 
Typically, you would expect mini side dishes before your meal. This one serve 6 variety of different appetizer but all in the same plate. I mean i was ok with it but even then the appetizer was not even that good.  
Overall, I would'nt come back to eat here again.
author: Carolyn C.

description: Nothing special but I like it.  One of the cheaper Korean restaurants in SF.  Food is good.  Good amount of banchan.  Plenty of parking since it's in the Safeway lot.  Even cheaper lunch specials.  Open til late to fulfill your late night Korean cravings.  Their budae jjigae is delicious.
author: Justine L.

description:
I love love love Arang. 

I give it 4 stars because K-pop sucks and they play loud K-pop. Other than the music, food is great! Decor is just like the restaurants that i used to go to when I was in high school/college in Korea, where students like to go. 

Straight up Korean food that reminds me of home. 

Their sea food stone bibimbap is their forte, i think. Everything is good....  i haven't tried their soft tofu stew since there are other korean restaurants specializing in soft tofu.
author: Helen K.

description:
Ahh yes, went here last night for nibbles but mostly booze.  Havent been back here in years. Their prices are decent.  Usually other places would charge a bit more for their booze.  We arrived at 11pm and it was dead.  5 min later the crowds began pouring in and we didnt leave until 2am.

Edamame
3 Large OB Lagers
2 bottles of Chamisul

Service: Attentive and the tea was pretty good as a chaser..yeah...I said it.  Parking is plentiful.  The waitress was cute but appeared to be overworked.  I hope she gets the tip I left her.
author: Sun T.

description: I came here recently for lunch and now I'm wishing I worked closer so I can add this place to my lunch-time rotation! Good and cheap Korean food; I'll be back :D.
author: Irene C.

description:
I've been here twice. Both times I ordered the bi bim bap without meat, mainly because that's what I can only eat on the menu. My friends ordered beef and chicken bento boxes. They seemed to enjoy it.

I like my bi bam bap, it was a good meal, although it made me really thirsty afterward. Their place is kinda small though.
author: Tina C.

description:
Korean restaurant is the only place for me to cheat. 
I usually don't eat beef, but here I purposelessly did. 
The hotpot with casserole.. with spams, sausage, noodle and rice cakee... Oh so good! I don't even know what kind of meat it is made of anymoree................ and now I feel so full of sin.

The Seafood pancake is okay, 3***
Bibimbap and bul gok si is okay~ 
Their side dish of Kimchee and friends is a 5*****, especially when such thins is free. 
The rice tea is 5*****
The service is another 5***** 
If you eat spicy food, go with the spicy ones.
author: Marlis T.

description:
Great little Korean restaurant.

I primarily go here only for lunch and get the bi bim bap. Good stuff =)

Its in a convenient location with plenty of parking since it shares its lot with a Safeway. 

Korean restaurant tend to be very expensive so this place is a very nice alternative.
author: Jasper L.

description: Went here during the weekend with my husband and his friend. My husband's friend said that it was his favorite korean spot in the city. It was just okay. Food is a little on the pricey side and you don't get much for what you pay. We won't be going back with him the next time he goes...
author: Mertani G.

description:
This place gets a 3 overall. I've had better korean food elsewhere. 
However, the one thing that they do very excellent here is the Seafood Pancake. 

I give the pancake 4.5 stars. I would come here, get a seafood pancake (or 2) some soju and continue your meal somewhere else. 

I often dream about this seafood pancake... its so good.
author: Jennifer T.

description: $$ might be overstating it. We paid $24 for two people for Bimbimbap. I had the one with kimchee, my friend had the regular with beef. Easy to park nearby. Would definitely go back.
author: Sam Z.

description:
Aaahhhh, this place reminds me of all the good o times after Avaron days but it's always been a special place b/c of  the great memories w/friends. The food is still pretty good after just recently going back  after many years and the food is very affordable compared to other Korean places. They have bomb lunch specials!

My Favs:
Chicken Teriyaki Box which includes: rice, miso soup, chapchae, pot stickers and salad. Lunch: $6.50 and Dinner is $8.95
Chol Myhon (Spicy chewy noodles) - ask them to make it a little less spicy b/c it is very SPICY. 
Mandoo Guk (Dumpling soup)
author: Deb C.

description:
Came here on a full stomach....but how do u refuse SPAM and hotdogs over ramen cooked at the table in spicy Korean broth??? You can't...not even when ur on a crash diet two weeks before your birthday...F the dress I need to fit into, right?  Then there was the omelette thingy with the sweet mayo sauce...that was good too.

They could have a better variety on their sides and shoju flavors though :(
author: Jenny K.

description:
I'm not a Korean thingy ma-jig tasting food specialist, but I know how to listen to my taste buds, so if I had to interpret tonguelish, they would say: 

"I wasn't disappointed; but I wasn't WOWed: I just simply enjoyed my meal coupled with my refreshing beer."
author: Tomasz B.

description:
After hearing how much I loved Toyose, my coworker suggested Arang as a Korean food alternative on those super popular dining out nights.  We hit up Arang with high hopes.

+ Parking lot, so we don't have to circle to leave our car in a safe area.

Had a bit of a wait since it was one of those nights.  Finally sat down, and was immediately disappointed by their drink selection (as compared to Toyose's seemingly endless flavors of soju).  Ordered some pineapple flavored soju, and it was S.T.R.O.N.G.  Definitely unlike Toyose, where the soju creeps up on you.

The food was good, but not super memorable.  The service, though, was kind of sucky.  I know we are at a corner table and we are short, but please, notice us already!  We were ready for the bill for at least 15 minutes before someone walked by.  Bleh!
author: Jenny L.

description: Talk about being pleasantly surprised. I had no idea what to expect when I walked into this dicey looking restaurant with 50s style dinner booths. What Arang lacks in decor, they more than make up for with the food. Perfectly seasoned beef and pork with hot rice wine and even a few surprise dishes. I'm not sure what some of the items were but my date ordered since she speaks Korean and I just trusted her that none of it was dog or cat! Now despite the language barrier with a few of the servers,  it is a frequent stop of mine when I'm craving Asian food during a San Fransisco visit.
author: Jay K.

description:
Nothing particularly special about this small Korean joint except that it stays open late at night serving alcohol and is the cheapest Korean place in this neighborhood.

I had the dolsot seafood bibimpbop.  Alas, most of the seafood was octopus, nary a sight of shrimp (except for one tiny shrimp tail) nor almost any other lovely crustaceans.  However, what can one expect when paying only $8.95 for seafood bibimbop.  

Banchan comes on a tv-dinner sort of tray (plastic dish sectioned out into 4 parts) with 2 types of kimchi (the usual baechu and small cucumber slices), vinegared julienned radish slices, thin sliced fishcake...I think a couple of other items I have since forgotten.  Basic.  Again, you are not paying a lot here.

Service was fine.  But please indulge me by speaking Korean to me when I speak Korean, even though my Korean is so atrocious. 

So, okay for the bucks, but definitely not a destination spot.  And there were two most annoying young men near us using large words, overwrought grammar and effected speech patterns in talking about Korean food and Korean culture without knowing much about either.  Sad--go read some history books before you speak pompously.
author: Sooj O.

description:
This is our new "go to" spot (our being me and my bf).

go to because we're too lazy to cook

go to because it's easy

go to because there is no food in the fridge

go to because it's cheap to eat, drink and dessert for less than 15 bucks a person

go to because it's right by where I live

go to because they do to go orders and it's good alternative to the fast food in the neighborhood and can feel more fufilling compared to Panda Express, Taco Bell/KFC, Subway & Popeyes

go to because they give you that damn good melon gum with your check -- as opposed to your typical mint

go to because they have good hours and are open late

but i guess if it weren't local, we probably wouldn't go to it as much.
author: Kat R.

description:
This place is hard to find, but a real good treat for late night korean.  It's atmosphere is very laid back and although it's a small place, there was plenty of seating and order options.

The tofu soup and spicy beef were both very good and flavorful, although the side dishes were a little odd.  Service was fine.

4/5 for the good prices, quantity of food, flavor and chill environment.
author: matt k.

description:
This is the worst korean food that I've ever had in my life... I'm not even Korean and I can cook better Korean food than Arang... I know this place is very special to EJ, but I don't think I will ever be able to like it... We stopped by here for a snack... In EJ terms, a snack is actually a meal... He had the dolsot bibimbap and I had the chicken katsu lunchbox... 

The rice in the dolsot was burnt and really dry... the veggies also very dry... the whole thing was just overcooked...

The chicken katsu had a really weird taste... not edible at all... The prices are definitely cheap for lunch, but since they food is so bad, they should be paying you to eat it...
author: Jen D.

description: This place seems pretty legit for korean food. However I was sad that there was only one type of tofu soup (but since it wasn't a tofu house, i'm not complaining) Also note that on weekends they only serve dinner during lunch time- aka its more expensive for the same thing. You can park in the safeway lot- major plus, since parking is terrible in the city. And it's not too far from Union Square- so it was a nice pit stop before some shopping.
author: Sarah S.

description: Good place, open really late. Big menu.
author: Michael E.

description: I like this place. The soju is great. It is very tasty and I couldn't detect the alcohol but I still got the after effects, if you know what i mean. ;) Anyway we came on a Monday at around 12 am and stayed till 2am. They came to refill our tea and gave us a little sampler dish that had kimchee, etc. I would come back here again!
author: Jenny T.

description: Love this place, open til late, good korean food!
author: Tanasan S.

description: My friend and I went to this restaurant by another friend's recommendation. It's basically a hole in the wall restaurant. No, like literally, the front was just a door. We walked in and seated ourselves, without much of a greeting from the staff. The tables were pretty small and very close together. It didn't make a very comfortable seating arrangement. We were quickly served with that barley or rice tea thing. It took a while before we could order, or get a glass of water for that matter. I requested a glass of water three times before actually receiving it. We ordered what was like a Kimchi hotpot and some fried chicken. The hotpot came very quickly. It was filled with Kimchi stew mixed with some random processed meat like spam and hotdogs, and a hint of ground pork, and some packaged ramen noodles topped with some refried beans. It wasn't very appetizing to look at or taste. It was the most bland Kimchi stew base I've ever tasted, and they weren't even generous with the "meat." It took a while for our fried chicken to come, and when it did it looked very.... well, it looked like they fried it while it was still frozen. It tasted like they didn't put ANY seasonings, not even salt. The staff wasn't very friendly towards us either. It was an overall disappointing experience.
author: Athena P.

description:
I think a lot of the hype that surrounds this place is b/c people usually associate this place as AWESOME EATS after clubbing/late night eats, b/c when I went there for dinner on a Wednesday (very sober), it was pretty lackluster. 

I couldn't decide want I wanted to eat. I haven't had kalbi tang in a while but I'm a total fire junky so I gotta have my spicy food. I ended up deciding that I needed more variety in my life, so I went for the kalbi tang, which wasn't bad at all. No complaints really. The broth had a nice flavor, this soup makes me all nice and tingly inside. I usually love having this stuff after snowboarding or on a rainy day, and slurp up the vermicelli noodles and be a cave man and chew on my huge honkin piece of rib.

But what I couldn't believe is that my friend ordered soon du bu and the waiter asked how spicy. He said, as spicy as you can get it. In all seriousness, please try to kill me kind of spicy. b/c we all know my Japanese friend todd, LOVES his spicy, maybe even more than me. 

My other friend ordered ra-pok-ki (ramyun and dukkpoki) no specific level of spiciness, but when the food came out, the tofu soup and the duk po ki, tasted exactly the same. I WAS SOOOO DISAPPOINTED, maybe a little embarrassed for my people. You have no idea how excited I was for them to just deliever this crazy spicy concoction, and it wasn't spicy AT ALL. 

There was no tingle in my mouth. I'm not exaggerating at all. I didn't know where all the red was coming from, b/c the thing was SO RED, but SOOO NOT SPICY. 


Sigh.... I can't go on, I'm so sad. My people are supposed to be the masters of spicy. -_-

If you don't plan on making it spicy, why even bother asking how spicy?


will i come back? heck no, there are way better korean places in the city.
author: Irene C.

description:
I've been coming here for years. Not for the service, b/c its just ok, not for the ambiance b/c there isn't any. But simply for convenience, and good-food for the price.

The servers, though not rude, have about as much personality as a fast-food employee.

In an area where parking is a luxury, you can't beat being able to park in the Safeway parking lot.

The 1-2 homeless that you may encounter are harmless if not entertaining.

After dinner, head over to Raselas for live music almost nightly...
author: Miguel O.

description:
Ate here for lunch today!  Although I've been coming here for almost 14 years on a weekly/biweekly basis and I must say the food is consistently good. 

I work out in the SOMA, so it's nice I can dine in and still make it back to work within an hour. The food comes promptly even though it's usually a packed restaurant during lunch hours. 

My picks are the kal-bi or spicy pork lunch boxes.  The cold noodles are  a treat on sunny warm days (but it's not always available).
author: Stacey L.

description:
Arang makes me so hot.

No, really!  Every time I eat here, I feel like someone has opened the sweat faucets.  The food is so delicious, HOT, SPICY, and delivered to your table in MASSIVE QUANTITIES!! 

The last time I went, I tried the dessert - OMFG!!  It was sex in a bowl.  Shaved ice with sweet bean and ice cream - topped with fruit and some cinnamon toast crunch cereal.  Jeeeez, why does it have to be so good.

I usually anticipate a wait to sit down and somewhat slow service, but the food is so good it's worth it.  While you're waiting you can enjoy gazing upon the Christmas decorations that are still up (it's September people!!) and enjoy the music selection (you'll know what I mean when you go).

Anyhoo...if you go and see a round eye girl sweating profusely in the corner - that's me!  So, make sure you say hi and have a shot of soju with me!!
author: Christy L.

description:
LA which is known as the largest Korean community, and then moving up to SF...the Korean food is mediocre.  I'd rather eat any other cuisine rather than Korean.  I can probably cook a better meal at my house.

Had there ddukbokki which was decent, but everything else there was just TERRIBLY BAD.  My sister told me she ordered a bento box for dinner and she got no side dishes and they were kind enough to give her some kimchi.  Kinda lame...
author: Jenny K.

description:
We went here based on the Chronicle's Cheap Eats recommendation, and were not impressed based on the other restaurants that have made their list (Ala Turca, . . .)  Maybe they were having an off day, but their food did not have any flavor.  I had the kimchi bi bim bap, which was not at all spicy, and my bf had the bul-go-gi combo.  Their hot sauce was kind of ketchup-esque, and coudn't save the bi bim bap.

Pros: open late and is very reasonable
Cons: not particularly satisfying, especially if you have other options
author: Cristina C.

description:
First came here a few years ago with my friend Sydney. and have been back a few times whenever in this neck of the woods and feelin for some korean, specifically Bibimbap. 

Rice beef mushroom carrot zucchini beansprouts and an egg delicately placed into a hot stoneware bowl, then i go ahead and mix it all up and add gobs of that delicious chili paste. so simple but its soooo good!

other good stuff, the kimchi fried rice, sauteed pork and veggies, and the banchan (as always!)

and its cheap! gotta try the lemon, yogurt, and peach soju next time
author: David D.

description:
This place has a Korean dessert you won't find in most Korean restaurants. It's called "Patbingsu" and it's typically made with shaved ice, fruit cocktail, azuki beans, and some form of milk and/or ice cream. Arang uses all of the above, and also throws in some Cinnamon Toast Crunch-type cereal to the icy mush. $5 for a bowl big enough for two people.

As for the food, I've only had the soon dae (Korean sausage) and ddukboggi (rice cakes and vegetables in a sweet, spicy sauce), which were both decent. This place is more of a casual meal/street food/drinking spot than a regular restaurant. That's why you won't get the full array of panchan with your food.
author: Jen C.

description:
Arang is a good Korean restaurant for those people who like to eat Korean food without the pricey tag to go with it. The place offer orders more on a single person dinner then large parties like many other Korean restaurant. 

You can get a Bento box "Arang combination sub for BBQ short ribs" and have almost everything you would want for dinner. At a typically, Korean restaurant you would have to order 1 dish which could be up to 20 bucks which comes with bunch of smaller side dishes.

At Arange you get a bento box and have a more personalized dinner for smaller parties with out the hefty prices.

The place is small and open late at night thats always a plus after a long night out dancing.

The only negative thing would be service. I always feel that they give better service to Koreans then all other guest. It like they are a bit for favorable to their own nationality.

For instance when order anything they should bring out the side dishes for you regardless if you asked or not. However, they only bring it for Koreans without asking.

Make sure you ask for the side dishes. That just part of the Korean food experience.
author: Taye N.

description:
It's not a GREAT Korean food restaurant, but Arang has some good strong points:

1) Tons of variety - this means that my group of friends (who aren't Koreans) can pick something they like
2) Price - Overall good value.
3) Parking - Plenty in the shared lot (with Safeway and others)

Bunch of us usually come here after our happy hour, and we always leave satisfied.  Oh by the way, if you call speaking Korean and ask nicely, they do reserve tables for you.
author: Eric P.

description: Arang is just another Korean restaurant in SF, but it's pretty conveniently located and the price isn't too expensive. I tend to think of this place as Korean fast food. I've never had bad service at Arang, and never had much f a bad experience. This place ALWAYS has customers when I go. I go there for lunch a lot because it's so close to work, and lunch hours seem to be verrrrrrry busy. The taste of food is just mediocre, but nothing really to complain about (considering I don't really think any places in SF are outstanding). The choices for food are numerous and cover a variety of different categories (soups/broths, noodles, rice plates, meat, lunch boxes, etc.). The reason for 4 stars? the fact that I've been here countless times since I was a kid and have yet to have a bad experience.
author: Hannah K.

description:
Only came here for the lunch specials . Everything was really decently priced, and the Om-rice I got was quite delicious. 

Will be back to try other things... man it was packed during lunch .
author: Lynn C.

description:
I haven't been to arang since... forevers.  I still remember vividly, the flavor soju that got me drrunnk off my @ss.  I was drinking with some Berkeley students, and I didn't even know them.  Ahhh those were the days.

Well, the boy and I were in J-Town, and I didn't really feel like having Japanese there, so the bf suggested Arang.

I was hungry.  So we ordered short ribs, kimchi stew with pork, and bibim naeng myun with a bottle of soju and a small bottle of peach soju.

Service was friendly.  Soju came first of course, and they gave us some free edamame to go with.  Peach soju was delicious but deadly.  I guess food taste EXTRA delish when you're a little.. buzz?  

Short ribs were unexpectedly delicious.  Tasted like the one you get from Korean bbq.  But dude, this place is clearly not Korean bbq.  It was GREAT and plentiful.  The Kimchi stew was really good.  They put some secret ingredient in it!  It was surprisingly good.  I mean, Kimchi stew SHOULD pretty much taste the same everywhere, but no... not here.  Bibim naeng myun was good, but not Sam Won http://www.yelp.com/search?find_desc=sam+won&ns=1&rpp=10&find_loc=oakland%2C+ca good.  But it was good.

With this amount of food and the intoxication level we were at, it would cost us lots elsewhere.  But Arang made it affordable.  We were happily buzz and full.  I passed out on the ride back.  Happy ending.
author: Gigi T.

description: This place is pretty good. The customer service is really good. My friends were like request so much things. Such as "More Water, Forks, Teriyaki Sauce, separate bills, etc." But the waitress was very polite and nice. I also liked the lunch special. Taste great. It's just that i found it pricey for the lunch menu, $8.95 for a combination lunch thing. I can find  a place with cheaper with bigger portions.
author: M L.

description:
Back in the day, when I was young and not a kid anymore...I used to come here a lot. In college, we would come here to eat late night, pretend to be gangsters, and underage drink. Its interesting that NOW I get carded for ordering a beer with my food, now that I am 30 and have two doctorate degrees. WTF?
     Anyways, the food is still good...even when you are sober. The Soon tofu soup was flavorful with the perfect amount of spice. It hit the spot and soothed my soul on this cold night.
     Bi bim bop was delicious but nothing out of the ordinary. Everything was seasoned well and I did get a little crunch (not much) from the stone bowl cooking the rice. 
     For old times sake I also got the shrimp fried rice omelet. This is one of those dishes that is the best thing in the world...when you are drunk. But sober...it was ok.
     Overall, the food was good, the service was pretty much non-existent (had to ask for the check), and the OB (beer) was luke warm. Eh...this place is better after tons of soju pitchers.
author: Siao W.

description:
Rude staff.  I expect the service at Korean restaurants to be minimal, but the owners/waiters here are sub-par even on those standards.

I had been here once before, because it's open late and it's somewhat affordable.  This last time, we waited for a table for twenty minutes, even as we saw numerous empty tables.  On top of that, the lady seats people before us.  One guy that was seated didn't even have the rest of his party with him, but she took him and his bad haircut to the open booth we were waiting for.

Done with this place.  I know the economy is bad so you have two people working fifteen tables, but you just lost business.  Like most Korean places in Japantown, this place is edible but not repeatable.
author: E L.

description: Came in here for some take out. Got the chicken teriyaki. The chicken was OK, but the real stickler was the amount of food for the money (10.50) for what should be a $6-7 lunch entree. I've had better Korean food.. I'd probably go back if they lowered their prices by 2-3 across the board, but there are other Korean restaurants to try in the area!
author: Ivan M.

description:
The first time I came here was after waiting about 3 hours to get into Toyose and finally giving up. We were told the wait would be 2 hours and after coming back in 2 hours we were told it would be 2 more. Some regulars outside told us chances are we wouldn't get a seat no matter how long we waited. So I was so thankful we ended up coming to Arang because we were seated promptly and people working there were very nice and friendly. The food isn't as good as what you'll get at a place like Meogeoboka or Ohganae but it's quite a lot cheaper and still tasty. Here's what I recommend here:

Sea food bi bim bap - actually very good even compared to other more expensive and nicer Korean restaurants

Beef bone and potato casserole - tasty and spicy, it has chunks of beef on the bone, potato, sprouts, jalapeno, other green thing, in a spicy broth. If you order the large one it can be enough for 3-4 people no problem.

Sea food pancake 

Mussel soup - I try to always end the night with this. It's so soothing and tasty, just mussels, white onions, green onions, jalapeno, salt and pepper. 

Soju cocktail - lemon one tastes the best for me

 
I also really have a crush on the waitress working here on Saturdays. She's really cute and nice. My friends think she's a little old for me but I think it's ok because she's so friendly. So that's a plus! 

So, I give it 4 stars because I don't think the food is really AMAZING like places in LA or Oakland or Korea House in Hayward, and the panchan is not really very good, but I always have a great time here and the food is good.
author: Mastiff B.

description:
foods is a little spicy.

got bim bi bop
friend chicken
short ribs
peach soju

everything was pretty good however the timing of the food was off the bim bi bop came like 10 mins before anything.

not bad and there is a parking lot next to it. which is usually a must in sf
author: Justin I.

description:
mmm cheap korean food and cheap soju! woohoo!! 

go for the lunch boxes, they're cheap and pretty decent. not too sure about the chicken katsu though, didn't have much flavor. well tasted more like chicken nuggets, but in a bad way.
author: Anh P.

description:
This place is good =) 

It took awhile for us to get seated because the place is kinda small and we had a big group! Once we were seated they brought out a soup (that was cooked on the table), which was really good and of course they brought out those mini plates of goodies (that you would usually get at a Korean restaurant). 

Everything we ordered was delicious!!!! We ordered spicy pork, Korean BBQ, Korean fried rice, and their spicy fried chicken! WOW ... the spicy fried chicken was really good! Should have ordered some to go but it takes awhile to make. 

We also had the peach soju =) That was okay for a drink with the family but I would just prefer just the soju!
author: Jenny M.

description: This place is awesome..love how they have a lot of parking for a SF location.  Came here a few times but I haven't been in years! Finally I came again today.  Place is great for groups.  Service is A+! Banchan was pretty good...i like their moo kimchee (the radish kimchee) They have pretty cool dinner boxes with plentiful food but just a few bux more you get the plate..the bulgogi plate was really good and I really enjoyed their bi bim bap.  They are pretty known for their sojus...i've had their regular ones and the peach one, i think, but that was many many years ago..now they have yogurt flavor, def want to try that next time but I was kinda hammed from earlier in the day.  Next door there is a karaoke..cool beans! Def want to come eat, get buzzed and go next door and sing ...sounds like a fun night one day!
author: Kimberly C.

description:
Very Few Appetizers, what gives??
Good Kimchi Chege, I can't help it, I love that stuff. I guess I really do use that as wether a restaurant is good or not. But hey we all have some type of food yeah?
I haven't tried much of anything else really, but everytime I go and I see my friends order other stuff, it kinda looks like a "bento box" We're in a korean restaurant right? Last I checked I thought so.

Anyhow...Service is alright, and I do have to say the decor is better than Won mi. However, there is definately a reason why Won-mi, which is accross the street, does better than this place...
author: Bianca L.

description:
seems to have a nostalgic feel for a lot of locals. 

BBQ short rib bento box ($12) was ok
Seafood udon ($12) was not very good
Free barley tea
Good service
Take out available

 Tip: don't park your car in the lot over the time limit. There is a person who walks around checking.
author: Jones T.

description: They stopped serving dried squid w/ peanuts, WTF?!... that should be negative 2 stars but I won't do it.
author: Gil A.

description:
I'm not a korean food critic by any means ... so since my bar was set super low, I have nothing but good stuff to say?

Had the bi bam bap ... was great. Came here for lunch and the prices blew me away! Reminded me of Vancouver. Yay for good, cheap korean food!
author: Emily C.

description:
Recently had a Korean BBQ smorgasbord (um, can you do that?) at Arang.  I love the way Korean BBQ makes meat taste like CANDY, I love the cool variety of sides, and really, I love anything that tastes good like that with white rice.  

The soju was just icing on the cake.

I spent most of the lunch chewing and moaning, I think.
author: M. H.

description:
Came here last night with a few of my friends and had a great time.The food was great, especially for the price, most korean restaurants charge a lot more than they do.. WOOT FOR CHEAP KOREAN FOOD! My friends and I ordered my the Kimchee fried rice.. which was so BOMB, meat casserole which had A LOT OF SPAM! I LOVE FREAKIN SPAM! anything with spam = delightful! The Kalbi was just right, great flavor and tender, Rice Cake with spicy sauce.... AHHH great flavor! Perfect amount of spiciness! and the seafood pancake.. my only complaint... where's the seafood... the only seafood inside was the squid! why not just call it SQUID PANCAKE! UGH! 

Parking was super easy, but i just wish it was in a better neighborhood.. but whatever! not as bad as the TL. Service was great... i don't know what everyone was talking about.. it's like any other asian restaurant... you just got to flag em down! 

Oh i forgot.... they have discounted alcohol! the beer and soju was crazy cheap compared to any other korean restaurant! WOOT crazy! I'll be back tomorrow!
author: Brian P.

description:
This little place is pretty hard to find. The only way to see this place is its front door. There isn't really a window or view of a sign to see. And the entrance points towards the safeway. 

The people are pretty nice. I have been here twice. They accidentally gave us the wrong food. They felt bad and didn't charge us for it. I liked their food. It was good. The rice thingy was great! The bbq ribs were alright. They had a different twist to it. it was like 3 long ribs. 

Generally pretty good, the best korean food that I have in the bay area. Of course, is nothing compared to LA though.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
I've been going to this place for years ever since college.  I have to say, food has not been the best when I first started coming here.  What brings me back is that it brings back old memories.  Over the years, the quality is actually getting better.  

I recently ate here again a month ago with a few friends after spa and I have to say, food was delicious.  We had the dumpling soup, kimchi fried rice, tofu soup, kalbi, and bi bim bap.    The soup tasted clean.  The kimichi fried rice had the hot and spicy kick to it.  The tofu soup was so so but that is because I can't eat really too spicy food.  I loved the bi bim bap.  

And the hours are superb with it being open so late.  4 thumbs up!
author: Helen O.

description:
My friend and I are die hard Arang fanatics.   We have been loyal customers since we were 19 and we used to go EVERY DAMN WEEK after our Bio class.  Once we arrive, it's like HEAVEN =)

This isn't like most Korean BBQ restaurants, in  my opinion, it's more of a fast food version of it.  

Things to try:
Any of their lunch/dinner boxes - the vermicelli and potatoes rock!
Gyoza - great everywhere (eat it with their hot sauce)
Spicy Tofu Soup
Fried Chicken
Seafood Bi Bim Bap
Soju!
Pickles - which they seem to have discontinued =*(

There's always parking, it's open late, you can eat and drink AND it's fairly cheap for Korean food.  WHY THE F NOT?!
author: Lisa W.

description:
Favorite Korean restaurant so far!  The service here is great, the lady greeted us in Korean too.  The price is reasonable and the wait isn't very long.  The place is cozy and nice, lights are pretty dim.. Good for small groups.

The food is awesome!  I love the appetizer plate they gave us with kimchi, fried spiced tofu, and all that good stuff.

The bibimbap is so cool, sizzling when served with a gorgeous egg on top.  The bento box food is also yummy, extremely filling!  It had a salad, rice, fried dumplings with noodles, and a variety of meat.  I tried the chicken katsu (kinda dry), beef (awesome), and seafood (okay, spicy). 
I'm not a very big fan of the udon or dough thing in soup (tasteless).  The kimchi fried rice was too oily.

Other than that, I would definitely come back with my friends to try the other food on the menu.
author: Anna L.

description:
A hole-in-a-wall type of Korean resturant. It's pretty small in here, which sucks.
